I quote the honourable member for O'Connor:
. . . the people who are treating farmers as fools are in fact the Grains Council and the National Party who say you're all dumb fellows.

As a result of the Government's latest initiative, the Liberal Party will have the guts, surely, to tell the National Party where to get off. The Nationals can no longer be regarded as just rural socialists; they are rural Stalinists, as emphasised by this morning's moaning and groaning from the Queensland politburo. It is at it again. Between the Nationals in Queensland and in Victoria it is 1987 all over again for the Opposition Leader, and he knows it. It all comes down to commitment of principle, the national interest, and that vitally missing ingredient in the Liberals' makeup-political courage. Senator McGauran is saying the Opposition still opposes the legislation, despite the wimpish agreement reached in the joint party room last week. Who is running the show on the other side? By delivering these new powers to the Australian Wheat Board, the Government will bring about important efficiency and service changes to State-run monopolies, such as railways and bulk handling facilities.

It will come as no surprise to honourable members that the Queensland Government does not want a bar of this. The Hawke Government's micro-economic reform runs are well and truly on the board. It is about time that people on the other side stood up for what they allegedly believe in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to respond to the honourable member for Dunkley by announcing that the Year of Citizenship has already been an outstanding success. In response to my letter to all households and the advertising campaign undertaken by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, about 50,000 people have requested citizenship application forms. Also, 45,000 people rang the 008 inquiry number between 12 January and 10 March. The response was so great and unexpected that at times the operators had difficulty dealing with the number of calls that came through. In addition to those 45,000 people--

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Peacock interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has already been asked to cease interjecting. He continues to defy the Chair. It was the Deputy Leader of the Opposition who interjected; the Chair was watching him. He will not do so again.

—In addition to those 45,000 people who rang, there were 66,000 written requests for application forms received so far in response to newspaper advertisements. I am pleased to say that in those circumstances the applications for grants of citizenship for the current year are already 36 per cent higher than in the previous year. I conclude by saying that these statistics, which are quite overwhelming, put the lie to the statements made by those who suggested that this was a hollow campaign with little purpose. It is quite clear that there has been reciprocity here. On the one hand the Government has made a significant effort to promote the benefits of Australian citizenship and on the other hand, I am pleased to say, the Australian community, as we would have hoped and expected, has responded magnificently.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Treasurer please explain to this House how a package of unfunded tax cuts and across the board wage increases which are quite unrelated to productivity is consistent with the call by the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia that every man, woman and child in Australia needs to cut his or her spending on imports by about $300 per head in order to bring our balance of payments problem under control?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member prides himself on having some technical facility, yet he has the audacity to say that tax cuts paid from the Government surplus are unfunded. That is what he said. That was the prelude to the question-that they are unfunded. They are entirely funded. They have been funded by the largest reduction in public sector outlays in our history.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite may laugh at that, but the fact is that Commonwealth outlays rose to 30 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) under the Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer. This year they will be 25 per cent of GDP and next year, 24 per cent. In other words, by the end of next year we will have Commonwealth Government outlays back to their early 1970s levels. It is that 6 per cent shift in outlays and the dramatic shift in the public sector borrowing requirement which have so changed the state of Australian investment. But, in relation to the Budget, it is a six percentage points change in outlays which has produced the surplus. The tax share in GDP today is exactly the same as it was in 1985-86. But the fact is that we have outlays of 25 per cent of GDP. That is where the surplus comes from.

ANSWER.PARA: To be parading around the country dishonestly referring to them as unfunded tax cuts or, even more dishonestly, suggesting that there has been no restraint in Commonwealth expenditure when we are in our third year of negative outlays growth, about to come into a fourth, reducing it to 25 per cent of GDP after the squalid spending on the Opposition side of politics in the period of the last Government of which the honourable member was an adviser to the then Treasurer, says little about his economic credentials. It leaves the honourable member's economic credentials where we think they are-nowhere. When the honourable member had an influence on this place, it was hidebound and regulated. Its fiscal policy was at the highest level of outlays ever. It had the most draconian and haphazard monetary policy in the world. It had no wages policy. Of what value was the honourable member as an adviser? Not content with wrecking the place once, in an amazing coincidence of personalities the coalition wants to bring back the honourable member for Wentworth, the Leader of the Opposition and Senator Stone, the three villains of the piece, to do it again-the Leader of the Opposition on his second go round. Anyone can slow down economic growth, but it takes a special kind of talent to make an economy contract, to make an economy get smaller. That is what the Leader of the Opposition did in 1982-83. He gave Australia the first negative growth in 30 years. And who was his principal adviser? It was the honourable member for Wentworth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Employment, Education and Training seen the results of a phone-in by young people in South Australia in which it is reported that many unemployed 16- and 17-year-olds resort to theft and prostitution to supplement their job search allowance? Can the Minister say whether these results have been reflected in other surveys?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Hawker for her question, in which she drew attention to what I would describe as a laughable but unfortunately cruel stunt that has been played on young people in Australia. This poll purports to give the results of a self-selected phone-in of just 61 people who responded to an exercise run by a group called the Campaign for a Fair Deal. The fact that 5 per cent of these callers-that is, three out of the 61-said that they wished to supplement or did supplement their income through prostitution is waved around as having some veracity. It also purports to say that young people are more interested in stealing than they are in working. One can imagine how the results of this poll might have been cooked up.

ANSWER.PARA: By contrast to this mickey mouse survey, the Government has conducted three major surveys during the period from 1984 to the present. The results of those surveys have influenced Government policy and have led to the development of a comprehensive policy for young people. During our surveys, the most recent of which was conducted in 1988, we took a scientifically selected sample of 2,000 young people nationwide and asked them a wide range of questions about their concerns and aspirations. Specifically, two-thirds of them supported the replacement of unemployment benefit for 16- and 17-year-olds by the job search allowance. Indeed, a majority of the unemployed young people themselves supported that move.

The central finding of that survey was that the three key issues of concern to young people were jobs, money and education. They were the underlying planks which led us to develop our policy, which actively promotes the acquisition of knowledge and skill by young people, thereby improving their employability, by encouraging young people to stay at school until the end of year 12. As a result, retention rates have increased from about 40 per cent to just under 60 per cent in the period that this Government has been in office. Our policy does not discriminate between young people in need of income support, whether they are in education or looking for a job. It also makes it possible for young people from economically disadvantaged families to stay at school longer.

Since we have been in office the number of Austudy recipients has grown by 132,000 or 75 per cent, and the rates of those allowances have in some cases almost doubled. The Government's policy also provides training opportunities for more young people than ever before in Australia's history. The number of apprentices has grown by 46 per cent and in 1988-89 15,000 young people will be joining the Australian traineeship scheme. Our policy also links income support for the young unemployed with constructive measures to help them obtain work. There will be 8,000 participants in job clubs and job search training courses, many of them through SkillShare. These initiatives combined have led to the fact that there are now 80,000 fewer teenagers out of work and looking for a full time job. Another policy has been foreshadowed by the Opposition. It is a policy which wants to make people work for the dole, a policy which introduces an unacceptable and indiscriminate form of compulsion. I can tell honourable members that under this Government there will be no return to the susso.

Beyond that, the campaign's South Australian survey is a massive slur on young people, because young people are not like what has been demonstrated or purported in the survey. Therefore, it brings no credit to the people who produced this survey's results and, I might say, to Senator Janine Haines who was associated with its launching. If she is prepared to believe those figures, it is not surprising that she believes some other cockeyed poll which suggests that she has some chance of winning the seat of Kingston. The fact of the matter is that young Australians are not interested in handouts or a life of dependence on the state. They want education, training and jobs. In short, they want the opportunity to succeed-an opportunity which this Government is giving them.

—My question is also to the Minister for Administrative Services. What is the Government's current practice regarding the application of preference arrangements to government purchasing? Are those arrangements under review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The policy with regard to preference as it applies to government purchasing, as it was implemented by the former Government and this Government, is under review by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and me. Current preference arrangements, as they apply to procurement policy, allow for a 20 per cent notional discount on Australia-New Zealand content on purchases over $20,000. As that is a notional discount, it is seen by many people in industry and the Government as a protective device rather than a measure to enhance the competitiveness, both locally and internationally, of Australian industry.

ANSWER.PARA: We have had extensive consultations with industry and trade unions and have received significant input from the Bureau of Industry Economics. They have reported to me and Senator Button. One of the interesting points to come out of the report is that they say that present preference arrangements influence only less than one per cent of total government purchasing contracts which amount to something like $8,000m per year. On the other hand, some industry sources say that the policy should be retained because, for one thing, it is a signal to local industry of government support, particularly at a time of very strong restructuring of Australian industry.

On balance, I could say to the House that I believe that there is scope for major change in the present preference arrangements-changes that would alter the present protectionist nature of that policy to a system which gives Australian industry an edge but at the same time still provides an incentive to Australian local industry to become even more competitive than it is now. So we are considering these issues. I would expect to put the submissions before the Government in the very near future and I would expect to make some announcements some time in early May.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support. Is it a fact that the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport cross-runway is in a state of disrepair and has been described as the roughest runway at any of Australia's major airports by Qantas Airways Ltd and domestic pilots? Is it a fact that the cross-runway is soon to be resurfaced? Will this operation take 18 months to two years to complete? What action will the Government take to ensure a smooth flow of traffic through Sydney while the upgrading is under way, or will passengers be subject to even further delays?

—The runway was last resurfaced in 1973 and the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) is now considering covering the entire east-west runway with a nominal 60 millimetres of bituminous concrete at a total cost of $3m. The work will be carried out during curfew hours to minimise disruptions to scheduled flights and to coincide with the Civil Aviation Authority's replacement of the instrument landing systems on the east-west runway. The total project will take approximately two months. Both the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and the FAC have confirmed that there is no risk to safety in continuing to use the runway during normal peak hour traffic periods and the project will ensure that the runway will be better equipped to meet expanding aviation needs.

—Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that no fewer than 12 aircraft landed from the north on the main north-south runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport between the hours of 11 p.m. last Friday and 2 a.m. the following morning and that these movements included a number of large jet aircraft types, such as Boeing 727 and Airbus A300? Did the Minister give a dispensation permitting these curfew breaches? If so, what was the reason? Can the Minister give an assurance that residents in suburbs surrounding Kingsford-Smith will not in future be subjected to this sort of outrageous intrusion during their sleeping hours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts as alluded to by the honourable member in his question are basically right. Last Friday night at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport traffic was allowed in the normal curfew period between the hours of 11.15 p.m. and 2 a.m. The reason for that was that industrial action had been taken by the air traffic controllers at Sydney which closed the airport on the busiest night of the week from 8.30 until 11.15. As a result, the airlines experienced very severe traffic disruptions. It was my view that these were exceptional circumstances that provided the appropriate circumstances for a dispensation to be given.

ANSWER.PARA: However, these were exceptional circumstances and it would not be my view that the continuance of industrial action at Sydney Airport involving its closure in the evenings would enable a continuing pattern of curfew dispensations to be given to allow flights during the night. Indeed, I can assure the residents in suburbs surrounding Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport that the noise reduction strategy introduced on 30 October last year will continue to apply. In this regard the Government has no intention to change or dismantle the curfew arrangements that currently apply for aircraft movements at Sydney Airport.

The serious dispute which lies at the bottom of this matter does not involve matters of safety or staffing but matters of money. This is simply a naked claim for additional pay, way outside the wage fixing guidelines, by a small group of members of one union who are acting against the wishes of the Federal body of the union. I understand that they indicated clearly at a meeting this morning their continued intention to defy their Federal union in relation to its proposal as to what was the appropriate policy to be pursuing. The fact is that there have been negotiations between the Civil Aviation Authority employing body and the union about an award restructuring which has already got to the stage where notification has been given to the Industrial Relations Commission that this matter should be brought before the hearing which is currently taking place to review developments in award restructuring. If proceeded with, it could result in air traffic controllers being amongst the first group of employees in the country to receive increases from award restructuring. However, the action is being taken by the Sydney air traffic controllers and supported by resolution, but so far not by industrial action by the Melbourne air traffic controllers which would put all that at risk and certainly create the situation in which there can be a continuance of severe disruption of aviation in this country by closing down periodically, if not more often, the major airport in the country. The Government's view of that quite clearly is that we will not tolerate the granting of a wage claim which is outside the wage fixing guidelines. Air traffic controllers along with everyone else have to abide by the wage fixing principles and the air traffic controllers at Sydney should understand that whatever industrial action they take will not lead to the Government taking action which would be a concession outside the wage fixing principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable members will recall that in November last year the Government announced a number of inter-related inquiries into the administration of Aboriginal affairs. The background to the establishment of these inquiries was material provided and statements made in Senate Estimates Committee processes, and elsewhere, alleging serious shortcomings in the administration, including financial management, in the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) announced in this chamber on 7 November 1988 that he had asked the Auditor-General to undertake a comprehensive audit of the Aboriginal Development Commission and to extend this, as appropriate, to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. He announced also that the Public Service Commissioner would be investigating questions concerning personnel management in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and that the Department of Finance would investigate any staff classification issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, he announced that the Government recognised that certain matters might still require further examination in the light of these specialised investigations and that the Governnent had asked Mr Andrew Menzies, am, obe, a former Deputy Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department, to make any such inquiry. The Auditor-General and the Public Service Commissioner are, of course, independent statutory officers, and the Government made clear that Mr Menzies would also be exercising an independent role in following up any outstanding matters. The Government also made it clear that each of these inquiries should be as thorough as those conducting them judged necessary. It was the Government's intention from the outset that, in the light of the outcome of these inquiries, it would consider whatever steps might be necessary to address any problems brought to light.

I am now able to advise honourable members that most of these various inquiries have been completed. The Public Service Commissioner and the Department of Finance have completed their inquiries. Moreover, as a result of a further request from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to the Minister for Finance, the Department of Finance has prepared a broader report on financial management in the Aboriginal Development Commission.

As honourable members already know, the Auditor-General has completed a substantial part of his remit, with only a report on some particular enterprise projects in the Aboriginal Development Commission area which were brought to notice in the Senate yet to come. Mr Menzies has completed an interim report which outlines the process he is following in his inquiries and the matters which he has excluded. In particular, he is not re-examining issues which have been dealt with definitively by the Public Service Commissioner, the Department of Finance or the Auditor-General in their reports. Mr Menzies has identified two issues in the Auditor-General's report which have not been or are not being dealt with to finality by the Auditor-General and which Mr Menzies sees as appropriate for his investigation. He indicates that these two matters are under active investigation, together with a comparatively small number of matters arising from submissions received from the public or otherwise brought to his attention.

Mr Menzies outlines in Part II of his interim report the matters under investigation but recommends that that part of the report not be published generally. The Government accepts his recommendations that, in view of the continuing investigations, Part II should not be published. It has, however, been made available to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) and the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Haines). I make the important point that, pending Mr Menzies' final report, I shall not comment today upon the conduct of any individual. Nor should others prejudge the findings. Attempts to ascribe guilt by allegation or smear are simply unacceptable and should not be pursued by anyone inside this chamber or outside of it. The Government also has, of course, the recommendations and views of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs.

The Government is confident, therefore, that the primary issues of administration in the area of Aboriginal affairs have been covered in all the reports we have now received. Against this background, I now table in the House all the reports referred to, excepting the Auditor-General's report which has already been tabled and Part II of Mr Menzies' report. With the bulk of the inquiries now completed, the Government is in a position to inform the Parliament of its views and intentions concerning organisational arrangements for the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio on the basis of thorough consideration of the material now available to us. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will be following me with a detailed statement concerning these arrangements.

The Government, of course, stands ready to refine its response, and undertake any further action, should that be necessary, when the remaining reports are received. They will, of course, also be tabled in the Parliament.

At the outset it needs to be acknowledged that administrative shortcomings, some of them serious, are evident in the area of Aboriginal administration. The Government does not sweep aside these shortcomings; nor will we shirk our responsibility to correct them. In the case of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Auditor-General found that, overall, there was a lower than acceptable standard of administration. Clearly, administrative practices in a wide range of areas will have to be tightened. The Government recognises this, the Department knows it and some steps have been taken already.

The Department of Finance concluded, in relation to certain staff classification matters, that the action taken by the Department was not well founded in terms of classification principles and processes. Honourable members should note, in this regard, that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has accepted the Department of Finance's conclusions, and the necessity of appropriate corrective action. On the other hand, I believe it is important to note that, as the Auditor-General's and Public Service Commissioner's inquiries found, some of the more vocal critics of the Department were unable to provide evidence to back their claims.

The Public Service Commissioner has not substantiated allegations of patronage, favouritism, nepotism and cronyism in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. No hard evidence was produced that would warrant investigation under the Public Service Act. The Public Service Commissioner's delegate, Mr H. B. MacDonald, found no more than that there was an occasional lack of prudence or judgment and that there were some deficiencies in the Department's personnel practices, most particularly an inordinate delay in approving an equal employment opportunity program. Mr MacDonald also concluded that it was essential to clarify the policy guidelines on Aboriginalisation-that is, enhancing access by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to employment in the Department.

The much more fundamental problems brought to light in these inquiries are in the programs administered by the Aboriginal Development Commission rather than the Department. The special audit report's major criticisms are directed at the way the Aboriginal Development Commission administers its enterprise funds-pointing to a number of failed enterprises and less than rigorous oversight by the Commission. In nearly all cases mentioned in the report, Audit found that the ADC had failed to apply the criteria set out in its legislation, and concluded that the most serious defects in administration were in the ADC's approval procedures.

It should also be noted that there are proposals in the broader Department of Finance report for a strengthening of administrative support in these areas, and for the exercise of greater control, through clearer and more specific ministerially endorsed guidelines. The Government has taken these findings into account in the response which I shall outline and on which the Minister's statement will elaborate.

Before outlining the Government's response to the findings of these inquiries, it is essential that I reaffirm the two basic principles at stake in this crucial area of government administration. There is, first, the imperative for self-management, by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, of Government programs designed to assist their well-being. If there is one lesson that emerges from 200 years of contact between the original inhabitants of this country and the Europeans who have arrived since 1788 it is this: that after all the benign neglect, the paternalism and the failed attempts at assimilation, we today realise that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders themselves are the best judges of their needs and priorities. In recent years, the imperative of self-management has received considerable bipartisan support and it is one to which this Government has shown its fundamental commitment.

Second, there is the thoroughly complementary imperative for proper ministerial responsibility and accountability for, and effective parliamentary scrutiny of, programs as a whole, especially in relation to their financial administration. The nub of the issue before us, then, is finding the right balance between the principles of self-management and of overall ministerial responsibility.

Many critics-including in this House-have failed to see this need for balance. They have drawn the facile conclusion that answers to the administrative shortcomings that have been identified, especially in the Aboriginal Development Commission, lie solely in winding back self-management.

The Government believes it is possible-indeed, it is vital-to strike a better balance; a balance that both widens and deepens the opportunity for self-management, and establishes a more appropriate means of financial accountability and ministerial oversight. That is precisely what the Government's proposed legislation for the establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission seeks to achieve. It seeks to widen the scope for Aboriginal self-management to encompass all of the programs undertaken within portfolio agencies, and to deepen its real effectiveness by giving Aboriginal people at a regional and local level a far more specific responsibility to determine priorities and outcomes. It seeks also to establish the right mechanism for ministerial involvement which will genuinely uphold the principle of accountability to the broader Australian community.

I take this opportunity to reaffirm the Government's determination to proceed with the ATSIC legislation. Nothing that has emerged from these inquiries has eroded the Government's fundamental support for the concept and nature of ATSIC. But we can and will draw on the work of the Senate Committee and on the inquiries to refine and improve the details. In his statement today the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will describe the Government's intentions on amendments to the ATSIC legislation, particularly in the light of the report of the Senate Select Committee.

I believe it is appropriate in this context to remind honourable members of some of the legislative history of Aboriginal self-management, and in particular to point out that the ADC itself was developed, under the previous Government, with a less than conventional level of ministerial oversight for a statutory authority. I begin by quoting the words of Senator Neville Bonner, the first Aboriginal member of parliament, in giving, on behalf of the previous Government, the second reading speech on the Aboriginal Development Commission Bill in the Senate on 21 November 1979. He said:

The Government, in introducing the Aboriginal Development Commission Bill, is taking steps to put into effect what I have been saying for a number of years-the placing into Aboriginal hands of the control of Aboriginal affairs.
He went on to say:

. . . Aboriginals will be responsible for the decision making. Of course (he said) this is not to say that Aboriginals also will not make mistakes. It is to be expected that we will as we all do. But Aboriginals should have greater sensitivity to Aboriginal needs and they will learn from any mistakes they make while exercising this responsibility.

As honourable members will know, the legislation to establish the ADC was not actually passed until 1980. The amended legislation, again in the words of Senator Bonner, was designed to `strengthen the commitment to self-management' and to achieve `further steps down the road to making equality a reality for Aboriginal Australians'. He was able to say that because the weight of the responses to the original Bill was to reduce the role of the Minister and expand the role of the Commission. I would also remind honourable members of some important points made in that 1980 Senate debate by Senator Chaney, the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. He said:
There is an element of risk in Aboriginal self-management. I think it is a risk which both the previous Government and this Government have seen as a worthwhile risk.
He also said:

I suggest to those Members of the Opposition who are concerned, that they look at the limitations of ministerial power in this Bill as compared to the Bills that the Opposition when in Government put through the Parliament in 1974 and 1975.
He went on to say:

I think they will see that we are progressing in the way that one would expect towards withdrawing ministerial authority. I do not suggest that the Bills that were passed in 1974 were wrong for their time. I suggest that, as one would expect, we are moving in a direction of increasing Aboriginal control rather than ministerial control.

The significance of this recital of the background to the ADC is that it shows without any question that both sides of this Parliament have made, and welcomed, moves to give Aborigines a greater say in the design and delivery of programs to advance their status in Australian society. We all have been prepared to accept what Senator Chaney termed `an element of risk'. In reaffirming my Government's support for ATSIC, I make the point that, given this legislative history, the proposed new Commission is the logical and appropriate next step for the advancement of both the great principles of self-management and ministerial accountability.

Not only do the reports of the inquiries not undermine the Government's belief that ATSIC represents the correct way forward-we are encouraged by some of the positive implications for ATSIC's basic structure in the inquiry reports. For example, the special audit report illustrates the problems which can arise when one agency, the Aboriginal Development Commission, confuses its activities in enterprise funding with its own wider socio-economic responsibilities, and those of other agencies. It also points up some difficulties the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has experienced in providing a balanced range of services to communities in response to their expressed needs. While the report does not draw any conclusion, the Government notes that such problems as these would be reduced by bringing the full range of programs under a single administration, by eliminating the potential for overlap, and by planning systematically on the basis of communities' and regions' own priorities. At the same time, the Government accepts that it cannot proceed with these changes without addressing as effectively as possible the administrative shortcomings brought to light in the various inquiries, and the need for accountability and appropriate ministerial involvement and parliamentary scrutiny.

The Government had already, in the development of the ATSIC Bill, sought to provide for greater ministerial involvement-through the Minister being able to establish guidelines within which the new body would be required to operate in the administration of policies and programs, and being closely involved in the monitoring of priority setting through approval of estimates on a regional basis. These controls are designed to prevent the possibility of any radical departures from the approved estimates and policy goals.

Honourable members will note that the Department of Finance report tabled today recommends that the Minister should be given a broad role to approve the estimates of the Aboriginal Development Commission; should consult on the Commission's corporate plan; and should issue broad policy guidelines, especially where financial administration is concerned. The ATSIC legislation which the Government is proposing will meet those requirements. We have, moreover, considered to what extent the thrust of those recommendations should apply to the ADC while it continues to function in the lead-up to ATSIC, as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will indicate in his statement.

Also relevant is the recommendation made by the Auditor-General that the Government review the business enterprise provisions in the ATSIC Bill. The Government has done so and a more detailed statement covering its consideration of both the general financial accountability and business enterprise provisions of the Bill will be made by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. The Government has also determined that it will respond to the problems raised in the various inquiry reports, and to the suggestions made by the Public Service Commissioner for strengthened support, in the following ways. We will amend the ATSIC legislation to establish an Office of Evaluation and Audit, details of which will be provided in the Minister's statement. We will ensure that adequate resources are provided to the new Commission to enable these audit and reporting functions to be carried out effectively.

We will make sure that there are sufficient resources, including for training and by way of a temporary infusion of specialist managerial skills, for the new Commission. The Public Service Commissioner's reports pointed to the need for better training and improved management practices, and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is discussing with the Public Service Commissioner the best way to implement those recommendations in the Department as it is now. Dr McIver, in her report last year, as consultant on the new Commission's staffing and administrative structure, also concluded that a very active staff development program would be vital in the Commission's early days.

Because the reports have highlighted the need for training Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who work in community organisations, if they are to function with proper financial management, the Government will look to how it can intensify its efforts under the Aboriginal organisations training program. More immediately, the Government recognises the need to spell out and clarify the policy of Aboriginalisation for specific staffing positions concerned with formulation of policy for, and direct delivery of services to, Aboriginals, especially within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the new Commission.

We will require that relevant Commonwealth agencies establish-in consultation with the Public Service Commissioner and relevant unions-policy guidelines on enhancing access by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to employment, and that appropriate equal employment opportunity plans be in place on the establishment of ATSIC.

It would not be appropriate to conclude this statement without making mention of those many people whose diligence and commitment to the cause of the Aboriginal people cannot be questioned. The efforts of so many of these Australians, Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal alike-including those in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission-are beyond the demands of duty. Indeed, some of the shortcomings that have been identified have arisen, not from base motives, but from a genuine determination to overcome the appalling disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

It is as a result of those efforts, over very many years, that government sponsored programs are, gradually, improving the health, housing, education and employment of Aboriginal Australians and are, steadily, strengthening Aboriginal communities through land rights, through enterprise development, and through the provision of services to improve basic living conditions.

My Government is proud that, in recognition of this vitally important work, we have continued to make substantial real increases in allocations to Aboriginal programs in an era when it has been necessary to wind back the growth in overall Commonwealth expenditure. The inquiries have submitted the administration of Aboriginal affairs to an extraordinarily detailed scrutiny and have produced a wealth of material and analysis in a relatively short time frame. The Government appreciates the effort of all of the agencies and people involved, and I take this opportunity to thank them for it.

Surely the time has now come, especially in this Parliament, to cease the constant stream of allegation which has dogged this vital area of government administration. The Government's approach is, as I have indicated, to draw upon the lessons from the inquiries and to look to the future-to ensure that mechanisms are put in place and support provided so that future administration is on a sound footing. We are determined to address administrative problems in a way which ensures a higher quality of future administration in this very important area of government and, in the long run, a higher quality of life and sense of belonging for all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

It never admits that; it is always somebody else's fault. I think that the Australian public are getting fed up with that cop-out. If ever there was a Minister who has demonstrated that if the Westminster principle means anything he should have gone, gone and gone many times before today, it is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand).

What I intend to do today in replying to the Prime Minister is to take the Prime Minister's own words. They are not my words; they are not the words of the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles); they are not the words of any of the external critics of the Government. They are the Prime Minister's own words, used in his statement today. He said:

. . . there is the thoroughly complementary imperative for proper ministerial responsibility and accountability for, and effective parliamentary scrutiny of, programs as a whole, especially in relation to their financial administration.

So I will take the Prime Minister's own test, that is, the imperative of proper ministerial responsibility. I will take the House through some of the things canvassed in these four reports. I will invite the House to make a decision as to whether this Minister has met the Prime Minister's self-proclaimed standard today. I will ask members of this House and others listening to this broadcast whether at the end of that examination this man, in any sense of self-respect, can remain on the front bench of this Government. I think anybody listening to the evidence, anybody realising to start off with that there were no less than four examinations into the administration of the Department, would agree with me. The pathetic excuse of the Minister is, `I have always wanted another structure, therefore I cannot be blamed for anything that goes wrong with the existing structure'. The Minister nods his head. That has been his excuse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't point.

—I will point, because the Minister is in the dock of Australian public opinion. I will go on pointing at him because he has disgraced his ministerial oath. He has not given a proper account of his administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Do honourable members know what this pathetic Minister's equally pathetic excuse is? He says, `I want another structure, therefore I cannot be held accountable for anything at all that goes wrong with the structure I think has to be changed and improved'. What an incredible proposition. That is the equivalent of the Treasurer coming into this Parliament and saying, `Because I would like the Treasury organised in a different way, because I would like some of the functions now in the Treasury to go to the Taxation Office, until that change takes place, you cannot blame me for any level of incompetence, administrative or ministerial, inside the Treasury'.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that the Minister has not exercised proper ministerial authority and control. The Minister has never been in control of his Department. Of the four major inquiries that have been held into Aboriginal affairs, by far the most damning is the Auditor-General's audit into the administration of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The audit report is an indictment of the Minister, and it is an indictment of the Prime Minister for allowing the Minister to continue to hold a ministerial position. It exposes maladministration at the highest level, but most important of all, it exposes a dereliction of duty that is unforgivable from a government which in this area, more than any other area of its administration, uses moral outrage as a political weapon.

If ever there was an area of government affairs where moral outrage was used as it is by this Minister and this Prime Minister, it is the area of Aboriginal affairs. Whenever one disagrees with the Minister or the Prime Minister one is bashing Aborigines or one is a racist. One is not allowed to have a different view. If one does, one lacks compassion for Australia's black citizens. If one disagrees with the Minister one does not understand the Aboriginal people. If one disagrees with the Prime Minister's constant professions of moral concern, moral outpourings and moral outrage about the Aboriginal people, in some way one is forgetting the history of this country.

I say to the Minister and to his guilt-ridden Prime Minister that the present generation of Australians has every reason to be concerned about the fact that the Aboriginals are the most disadvantaged cultural group in our midst. We on this side of the House will yield to nobody in this Parliament or elsewhere in our concern to improve the lot of Australia's Aborigines. I also say to the Government and to the Minister that they will never improve the lot of Aborigines in 1989 and beyond by empty symbolic gestures such as treaties. I take the opportunity of saying again that if the Government wants to divide Australian against Australian, if it wants to create a black nation within the Australian nation, it should go ahead with its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation and its treaty. In the process it will be doing a monumental disservice to the Australian community.

I say to the Minister and to the Prime Minister that all the breast-beating today about the Government's concern to get the ATSIC legislation through and all the breast-beating by the Prime Minister about the necessity for a treaty will not in any way divert the public gaze from the fact that these four reports have permanently crippled the Minister's credibility as a Minister in this Parliament. They ought to have permanently crippled his credibility as a member of the Hawke front bench. If anybody thinks that I am indulging in any exaggeration or any hyperbole, let me just read what the audit report had to say. It said that the policy guidelines of the Department are `out of date, unrealistic, not relevant, not measurable, ambiguous and too narrow'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That was said in the audit report. It was said of a department that this man has had responsibility for. He will say, `That is not my fault; it is Clyde Holding's fault. It is somebody else's fault. If you had given me ATSIC there would not have been a problem'. But who is responsible? Who lays down policy guidelines? They are not laid down by the Public Service; they are laid down by the Minister. Policy is the responsibility of the politicians. Carrying out policy is the responsibility of the bureaucrats. How does the Minister escape that responsibility? He does not. He ought not be allowed to escape that responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: But the ministerial standards of the Hawke Government are so contemptibly low that Ministers can get away with any measure of ministerial irresponsibility and lack of accountability and still go on smiling. `Westminister responsibility', says the Prime Minster, `what does that matter? That is some fuddy-duddy old notion about doing the right thing, telling the Parliament the truth and being responsible for the mistakes that are made in one's name, with one's knowledge, connivance and encouragement. Let us not get worried about fuddy-duddy notions about ministerial responsibility. We do not want to get concerned about that'.

The audit found that $500,000 provided for consultation in relation to the treaty was contrary to the purposes of the ADC's Act and consequently illegal. But that is not the end of the matter. The reports go on to say very plainly what a litany of failure this Minister's administration has been. I waited in vain for the Prime Minister, in his nine-page statement-this man who is always parading his candour, his honesty and his straightforwardness to this Parliament and the Australian public-to acknowledge that this report had really been damning of the administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the ADC. But oh no! The Prime Minister, in typical style, grabbed the statement in the report that was the most favourable to the Minister, presented it as representative of the flavour of the report and then invited us to accept that all ought to be forgiven. Now, after four examinations and after the excruciating embarrassment of exposure before the Senate inquiry, where the work of such people as Senator Tambling brought to the attention of the public the disgraceful maladministration of this Department, the Prime Minister says, `We ought to forgive it all, because now they have been exposed and found out, the Department of Finance has extracted an undertaking from those in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs that they are going to be good boys in the future'. The Minister nods his head as the Prime Minister says, `That is right. That is a big concession to parliamentary and ministerial accountability'. The Government asks us to take seriously a Minister who, for months and months, has presided over this shambles; has been found out; has been excoriated in a number of reports; and has been rapped over the knuckles by the Auditor-General and sundry other inquirers. The Department of Finance has said that the Minister's Department is in a mess, but because, at the end of all of that, the Minister has said, `In future I am going to be a good boy', we are expected to clap him and walk away saying, `Good on you, Gerry. You are doing an absolutely terrific job for the Australian Aborigines and the Australian public'.

Just as it is becoming futile for the Opposition to raise points of order in this Parliament, it is also becoming futile to expect the Minister, or the Prime Minister, to apply the ordinary standards of ministerial responsibility. If the Minister had been a member of Whitlam's administration he would have been out on his ear months ago; let alone had he been a member of any administration on our side of politics, which applies proper standards of ministerial behaviour and accountability.

If anyone imagined that the charge laid by the Opposition against this Minister and this Government was confined to maladministration, incompetence, or ministerial failure, he or she would be mistaken. The issue goes beyond that. The Opposition also charges the Minister with having misled this Parliament. It is not sufficient for him to have been an incompetent administrator; he has also misled this Parliament. Let me give the House a classic example of the standards which this Minister has adopted, in terms of accountability to this Parliament. On 6 March last, my colleague the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs asked the Minister a simple question. He asked the Minister whether he stood by his earlier statement that at a meeting with State and Territory Aboriginal Affairs Ministers last November, the Minister had said:
. . . we had unanimous decisions . . . on every issue raised there.
I invite all members of the Parliament to listen to the Minister's reply:
There was a tied vote. Therefore the vote lapsed. There was a unanimous decision that I would write to them and I would communicate with them. Therefore it is unanimous.

The Minister blandly gave that reply. He then chose to regard himself as having given a proper account to this Parliament. On tests of accountability, ministerial candour and ministerial and bureaucratic competence, this man no longer deserves to be a Minister in the present Government.

I wish now to deal with one or two aspects of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation. The Government announced this afternoon that it intended to go ahead with the implementation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill. As members well know, this Bill has been scrutinised by a Senate inquiry. Many concerns have been voiced by both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people. It is hard to feel confident, in the face of those expressions of concern, that this Government is making a rational and sensible decision. The minority report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs said that many Aboriginal people simply did not understand the legislation; they were taken for granted; they were not adequately consulted; their support was assumed; and they did not think the legislation should be proceeded with. We on this side of the House cannot, and will not, ignore those statements. We do not believe that the Government has effectively addressed those concerns or statements.

There are many commentators on this issue. The pathetically inadequate selective quotations by the Prime Minister of what Senator Bonner and Senator Chaney said eight or nine years ago in relation to entirely different legislation do nothing at all to remove the concerns that I have expressed. Many commentators have pointed to the dangers of legislation which takes the principle of self-determination for Aborigines to the point of creating completely separate representative structures. I think it is a very bad step for the long term unity of this country to establish the structure envisaged under the ATSIC legislation. The Minister can look as grave and earnest as he chooses. He can express the moral outrage that is the stock in trade of the Hawke Government on Aboriginal affairs issues, whenever it gets into a jam, which is usually the case on anything remotely connected with ethnic or racial difference. The Government always gets into a lather of moral outrage in an endeavour to intimidate anybody who disagrees with it. But the concern about the sheer national idiocy of creating one nation, separate and apart from the rest of the Australian nation, is not a concern confined to the Opposition parties in this Parliament. There are many people right across the political spectrum-constitutional lawyers, media commentators, State and local bodies, and ordinary Australian citizens of every different background-who are concerned.

If there is one thing, above everything else, that we in this Parliament should regard as our sacred and absolute duty, it is the preservation of the unity of the Australian people. The ATSIC legislation strikes at the heart of the unity of the Australian people. In the name of righting the wrongs done against Aboriginal people, the legislation adopts the misguided notion of believing that if one creates a parliament within the Australian community for Aboriginal people, one will solve and meet all of those problems. I say to the Minister that if the Government establishes this ATSIC legislation it will create more resentment and more division. Where it seeks to produce accord, peace and harmony, it will sow mistrust, resentment and division. The Minister and his Prime Minister will be held accountable by the Australian people for having done that.

I remind the Minister of what Professor Colin Howard said. He is not one of my relations; he is certainly not one of my political confreres-he is a former political adviser to Lionel Murphy. On this issue, writing in a recent review, Professor Howard said:
. . . in the long run it is folly to enact a racial law which manifestly divides Australians instead of uniting them.

I ask the Minister, the members of his Government, and those many thousands of misguided supporters around the country who passionately want to help Australia's Aborigines-as do so many on our side-to think again. This is even more important than my criticism of the Minister, serious as I am in that. If the Government enacts this legislation it will create statutory division in this country which it has not had before. The only way to bring about a proper accord between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians is to embrace Aborigines fully within the Australian community; to treat their deprivation and their disadvantage-which I do not dispute-as a manifest responsibility of the entire Australian community. The Government will not lift up Aborigines, embrace them, and right their wrongs by signing treaties or creating black parliaments. It will bring upon them more distrust, more hostility and more misunderstanding. I ask the Government not to go ahead with the legislation. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`this House condemns the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for his failure to correct the defects in the administration of Aboriginal Affairs which were apparent from the time of the dismissal of the Secretary to his Department as revealed by successive Government reports.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Miles

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.
