DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION: THE WAY AHEAD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It is now 16 months since I first made a statement in this House outlining the Government's proposals to significantly restructure the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. In that time, much has happened. We have had the most extensive consultation ever on a piece of Commonwealth legislation affecting a particular group of people. We have had a significant response to the proposal from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people right across the country. We have had a politically motivated smear campaign from the Opposition to try to thwart the plans of the Government and the Aboriginal community. But the Government is determined to proceed with its legislation establishing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC).

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal to establish ATSIC was announced on 10 December 1987. Since that time we have made many modifications, taking into account the views expressed to me and others during the extensive consultations with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Today I will outline additional changes. Many of these changes deal with the question of accountability. This is an area which, I remind the House, is just as important to Aboriginal and Islander people as it is to government.

During the consultations I had with communities around the country on the ATSIC proposal Aboriginal and Islander people stressed to me that they did not want to be set up to fail. They did not want to take part in the decision-making process if it meant operating under flawed legislation. They were happy to accept the increased responsibilities but only if they received the necessary resources and training for the job. They did not want to be blamed for other people's mistakes, which has happened too often in the past. The Government has no intention of setting Aboriginal people up to fail. ATSIC will be provided with proper training and resources. But the legislation will also provide a series of checks and balances to ensure that all participants in the decision-making process-from the regional councils through to government-are accountable.
The basics of ATSIC will not be affected by any of the changes I will announce today. I remind the House of the main features, as contained in the Bill passed by the House last year:

a system of regional councils, elected by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders resident in that region, which will determine priorities, develop regional plans, and generally represent the interests of the region;
commissioners, of whom the majority will be elected by regional councillors grouped into zones for this purpose;
the Commission replaces the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC);
programs would be administered by Commission staff with funding direct to Aboriginal organisations and individuals;

other portfolio bodies-Aboriginal Hostels Ltd (AHL) and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies (AIAS)-would retain their independent existence, but would have three ATSIC commissioners on their governing bodies;
staff would come under the Public Service Act;
the Minister's powers would balance the requirements of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander self-management with those of accountability to the Parliament;

a new body, the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation (AEDC), would be formed to provide finance and services, on an independent commercial basis, for major enterprises involving, and of benefit to, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

Thus ATSIC will combine, in the one organisation, the means for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to have a real say in the management of their own affairs with an administrative structure that eliminates existing overlaps, is more responsive to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander wishes, and attains appropriate standards of accountability for public funds.
Accountability

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has already spoken of the Government's response to the findings of the Auditor-General in his special report on the ADC and on the Department. I affirm our resolve to address the problem areas identified in that report with vigour and determination. We have examined the Auditor-General's findings to see where they may bear upon the ATSIC legislation, and in particular on the provisions relating to accountability. At the same time we have taken into account the report of the Department of Finance into the ADC's financial administration. Both these reports lend support to the view that our proposals for ATSIC will result in a more effective administration of Aboriginal affairs. It is already the case that the ATSIC Bill contains stronger provisions than the ADC Act-for example, through the authority of the Minister to approve the estimates, which he lacks under the ADC Act.

Changes to the Bill must be considered in the context of the basic principle of ATSIC that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should have greater control over matters affecting them. The question is one of balancing this principle with the principle of ministerial accountability for the correct and efficient use of public funds. We therefore propose that the ATSIC Bill be amended to:

establish within ATSIC an Office of Evaluation and Audit, to undertake evaluations and internal audits on programs, projects and procedures. Project evaluations will be on a continuing basis, while for programs and regions there will be a three-year cycle of general audits. More intensive examination will of course flow from any shortcomings revealed in the general audits. The Office will report regularly to the Commission and the Minister, and annually to the Parliament through the ATSIC annual reports. The head of the Office will have senior rank and will be appointed by the Minister;
require ATSIC to observe financial directions to be made by the Minister;
require ATSIC to keep the Minister informed about specific projects that are encountering difficulties;
require ATSIC to prepare a corporate plan and to consult the Minister about it; and
clarify the distinction between commercial and non-commercial activities-a problem which has bedevilled the ADC.

It might be noted that one of the recurring criticisms by the Auditor-General was that projects were funded without there being community plans against which to assess priorities. The ATSIC Bill addresses this need. Coordination of community and regional planning is one of the functions of regional councils.
Senate Select Committee

The Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs reported on 28 February on the ATSIC Bill. Senator Tate, who represents me in another place, is tabling today the Government's responses to the recommendations of that Committee. We have accepted, in whole or in substance, the great bulk of the recommendations of the majority report. Those recommendations include, I point out, support for the Bill proceeding in the Senate.

I shall confine my comments here to the more substantial proposals for change to the Bill, commencing with those relating to the regional councils and the election of commissioners. The Select Committee expressed some concerns about the disparities in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander populations as between regions in a zone, and as between zones. These differences exist because we have sought, as a result of the extensive consultations which have been held, to accommodate the wishes of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as to where boundaries should be drawn, thus taking into account kinship ties and community of interest. This has undoubtedly been the right approach. Comparisons with legislatures and the principle of one vote one value miss the point; ATSIC is not a parliament.

Nonetheless the Government recognises that a system where one region in a zone with a small population has the same voting strength in elections for a commissioner as a much larger region, has some inequitable features. Accordingly we accept the Select Committee majority's recommendation 11 to provide a sliding scale of regional councillors, starting with 10 for regions with populations of under 1,000, with an additional councillor for each additional 1,000 or part thereof up to a maximum of 20-the number presently in the Bill.

We have also addressed the issue, identified by the Select Committee but on which it made no formal recommendation, of substantial population imbalances as between zones. To this end we propose that the five most populous zones be split in two, thus raising the number of elected commissioners to 17. In New South Wales, the Sydney region will comprise a new zone, as will the Perth region in Western Australia. The Northern Territory zone, which comprises much of the Northern Territory, will be split into two separate zones.

In Queensland, which has the largest Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population, two new zones will be created. One is for the Brisbane region, and the other to accommodate the wishes of people living in the so-called DOGIT communities-those who hold a form of title to their land under deeds of grant in trust-to be encompassed within the same zone. A new map is being drawn up to show the proposed changes. I believe these proposals will make for a better balanced system of regional councils and, through the revised zone structure, a more equitable system for the election of commissioners.

Recommendation 12 proposes, inter alia, voluntary enrolment for regional council elections, but compulsory voting for those who do enrol. The Government's intention has been that no special roll be established and that, as with the elections for the former National Aboriginal Conference, voters fill out a `voter card' on the day. There would be mechanisms for testing the eligibility of voters to take part in the election.

The Government appreciates that the Select Committee has been concerned to find a system which would provide both the opportunity for persons of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander descent to choose whether they wished to vote in regional council elections and a means for checking the eligibility of voters. The Government has given careful thought to voting systems. In its view the overriding consideration is that a public roll based on race, whatever its purpose, should not be established in this country. We will explore possible alternative systems with the Australian Electoral Commission. The details will be contained in the electoral rules which I am to prescribe in accordance with clause 95 of the Bill; that clause provides that the Parliament may disallow such rules.

A number of the recommendations are for tightening up existing provisions of the Bill. They deal with such matters as eligibility for elected or appointed office, pecuniary interests, full written assessments of proposals before substantial expenditures are approved, acting appointments, and employment of consultants. The Government accepts these recommendations, with some modifications to bring them in line with the require-ments of other organisations established by statute. Although it modifies the Government's original intention to bring all bodies in my portfolio under one umbrella, we will also accept recommendation 3, which proposes that the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies should continue to be established under its own legislation. Other aspects of the proposed reforms to the Institute's structure will proceed.

The Select Committee looked closely at the preamble to the Bill. The majority, while recognising that concerns about possible wider ramifications of the preamble were not well based, has suggested that it could help to allay such concerns if the preamble were removed from the Bill and moved separately, without amendment, as a resolution of both Houses. The Government stands by its conviction that the preamble is of such significance that it should not be separated from the Bill. Australians should not back away from acknowledging, in a symbolically important way, the facts of history and our resolve to address the present effects of past injustice. We will not be diverted in our purpose by those who have chosen to represent the preamble as having a degree of legal force that it does not possess.

The Select Committee's recommendation 2 is important, and has received close attention. It proposes that enterprise and related functions of the ADC be transferred, not to ATSIC as the Bill proposes, but to the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation-the AEDC. ADC's housing functions, however, would transfer as planned to ATSIC.

The Government has decided not to transfer those functions to the AEDC. The reason for this is that the AEDC is intended to operate in quite a different way. It will not administer programs but will facilitate and participate in significant commercial enterprises involving, and of benefit to, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It would be inappropriate, and would dilute the commercial nature of the AEDC, to have it take on programs, especially programs which include quasi-commercial aspects such as grants and concessional loans. ATSIC, through the regional council planning processes, is designed to accommodate a whole range of community needs and in so doing will reduce the present wasteful duplication of administrative structures, including field services. I note here that the recent report of the Auditor-General has highlighted the problem that the ADC has often faced in separating its commercial and social functions. Maintaining the AEDC as a strictly commercial body will help address those concerns expressed by the Auditor-General. The ATSIC Bill will improve the capacity of the Minister to oversee enterprise activities in line with recommendations made by the Auditor-General.

With regard to the first recommendation of the Senate Select Committee that a separate Office of Aboriginal Affairs be retained within the Employment, Education and Training portfolio, I should point out that the ATSIC Bill does not restrict the advice available to the Minister to that provided by ATSIC. Indeed, it was always envisaged, under the ATSIC proposal, that there could be circumstances where the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and also the portfolio Minister, might occasionally require separate departmental advice on issues concerning ATSIC, and that this advice would come from the portfolio Department.

It will be clear from what I have said that the Government rejects the minority report of Opposition senators in seeking to have the Bill withdrawn. They have not established a case. Their report is long on assertion and colourful phrase, but woefully short on accuracy and fact. For reasons best known to themselves they wish to perpetuate a system-a system which they created-which is patently not working as it should. It is not a system for meeting the legitimate expectations of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people for a real say in their own affairs.
Other Changes

The opportunity will also be taken to make a number of other changes, essentially machinery and minor in nature, to the legislation-for example, in relation to dates of operation. A summary of the main changes to the ATSIC legislation is attached to the printed copies of this statement.
Implementation and Timing

ATSIC has already been delayed well beyond the original proposed starting date. That has created considerable problems for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, who naturally wish to know that promised and needed reforms will not be put off again. The delays have also left portfolio staff uncertain about their futures. In addition they have had to deal with a constant barrage of abuse from the Opposition as well as cope with the onerous task of responding to hundreds of questions on notice which have taken them away from their normal duties. I am very conscious of the additional difficulties this has caused for them, as it has for portfolio management. I take this opportunity to express my gratitude for the way in which portfolio staff have continued to undertake their demanding and important tasks with commitment and efficiency, in often trying circumstances.

There are still some reports to be completed, including a further report by the Auditor-General and some investigations by Mr Andrew Menzies. It is unlikely that these reports will show a need for further legislative change, but should it prove to be otherwise I shall, of course, bring forward proposals for such change. The timetable that I propose for implementing ATSIC takes this into account. I would also add that we will continue our consultations with the staff associations in the lead-up to the implementation of our proposals.

The amendments I have outlined are important but do not affect the substance of ATSIC. We believe they will be widely welcomed and acceptable as desirable improvements. We therefore propose to press ahead with the legislation in the present sittings of the Parliament. Once the legislation is passed, there are a number of processes to be completed before the new Commission can become fully operational. These include the holding of regional council elections, the processes for which will take some months, and the election by regional councillors of the commissioners.

The Government is very conscious of the need to minimise uncertainty and avoid further drift. It is also very conscious of the degree of confusion which has been generated in the community as a result of the political campaign waged by the Opposition. At the same time we recognise that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people need time to understand the changes that are being made and, more broadly, to get to know more about ATSIC and how it will work. They need to have this information before being asked to make the important decisions of electing their regional councillors and then those regional councillors electing com- missioners.

Our preferred course is that the commission be established on an interim basis from 1 October 1989. This will be done under transitional arrangements which will allow for the appointment by the Minister of five commissioners, including the Chairperson. This arrangement will have a 12 months sunset clause.

We would then allow an extensive period for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to become familiar with the way ATSIC will work, and for the administrative structure to shake down. A major educative and training effort will be made during this time. Regional councillor elections will then be held, and ATSIC would become fully operational within this 12-month period. This phasing-in approach will help ensure that ATSIC comes into operation smoothly and effectively.

Already the ATSIC concept has been open for consultation and comment for over 15 months. We have made a series of refinements and modifications as a result of those processes. We will also ensure that ATSIC is properly resourced to undertake its important tasks. In its management and administration, ATSIC must have its priorities right from the start. It will have to put a lot of effort into such areas as corporate planning, program budgeting, policy and program guidelines, and evaluation and internal audit.

Another vital need to come out of the inquiries is for a much improved training effort to enhance the skills of those working within Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations and of portfolio staff and to ensure that ATSIC is properly understood by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

Some State and Territory governments-this was referred to by the Leader of the Opposition-have expressed concerns about ATSIC. I have sought on a number of occasions to provide opportunities to meet with them and I am continuing to do so. This is notwithstanding the fact that no State or Territory should have anything to fear from ATSIC. It appears, however, that some are happier to complain rather than put their views to the test.
Immediate Needs

ATSIC will not be operational for some months, but there is clearly a need, identified in the reports of the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General, to act now to remedy deficiencies within the present structures. We shall ensure that the ADC, during its remaining life, operates on a similar basis to ATSIC and in a manner that properly reflects Government priorities. The problem lies, at least in part, with defects in the ADC Act. By a combination of amendments to the Act, cognately with the ATSIC legislation, and of directions to the ADC under section 11 (1) of that Act, we will require ministerial approval of estimates and consultation on its corporate plan; issue broad policy guidelines, especially relating to financial administration; and empower the Minister to request information and advice. A summary of the main proposals is also attached to this statement.

As far as my Department is concerned, problems identified in the reports can only be addressed by administrative action. This action is currently being taken. In this regard I am able to report that considerable progress has been made in respect of a number of matters identified by the Auditor-General as requiring improvements. These include: substantive work on the development of revised performance indicators; the acquittal of grants to Aboriginal organisations; revision of financial guidelines for grants; and the acquisition of additional field resources for some regional offices of the Department.
Conclusion

The changes we have made to ATSIC have not come about as a result of actions by the Opposition. It has had the opportunity but has failed to make any constructive contribution. The Opposition has only sought to delay the proposal and generate confusion within Aboriginal and Islander communities. The Opposition has demonstrated that it is not interested in any kind of progressive reform. It is certainly not interested in Aboriginal people being part of the decision making process. The only conclusion we can draw from the Opposition's stance is that it cannot accept the role of Aboriginal people as decision makers. It cannot accept that Aboriginal people must be part of the processes of government. It cannot accept that Aboriginal people are the ones who can best determine their own needs and priorities. I am happy to say that the Opposition's efforts have clearly failed.

Now, for the first time, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians will have a real say in matters affecting them. We are putting an end at last to paternalism, to the idea that others must decide what is best. We cannot amend history, but we can act to correct its adverse effects for today's and tomorrow's Australians. That is what ATSIC is all about. It is an achievement of which all Australians will be proud.
For the information of honourable members, I present the Government's response to the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs.

In my speech earlier I indicated that the ADC, during its remaining life, should operate on a similar basis to that envisaged for ATSIC and in a manner that properly reflects Government priorities. I also went on to say that what problems have been experienced have been at least in part because of defects in the ADC Act. I want to highlight this point about the significance of the problems of the Act for it has been all too easy for this to be overlooked. Indeed, this problem has been substituted by attacks on individuals. ADC commissioners all along, but especially the present ones, feel very strongly they have been working to make the ADC effective in advancing the interests of Aboriginal and Islander people and yet been criticised unfairly. I want to take this opportunity to make it clear that the task of the ADC commissioners has been a difficult one which they have striven to handle well.

In the light of this criticism it is important that any action I take can be seen as assistance for their task. I believe the Auditor-General's report and the report of the Department of Finance have highlighted the need for consistency of action across the portfolio. I therefore now table a set of general directions to the Aboriginal Development Commission which I have issued under section 11 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980. In essence these directions, as I said at the opening of my remarks, ensure that the ADC will operate for the remainder of its existence on a similar basis as envisaged for ATSIC.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission: The Way Ahead-Ministerial statement, 11 April 1989.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The clear reality of today is that we would not be here having this debate if it had not been for the work of the Opposition in highlighting the lack of accountability in Aboriginal affairs and the shambles and chaos that we have seen over the last six to eight months. That is the reality of today. There would be no debate, there would have been none of these reports and there would have been no Senate select committee looking into the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). Let us put it down quite clearly at this stage that this debate would not have taken place and the Australian people would not have been alerted to the absolute chaos and shambles of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) which we have seen now for six months.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government announced today that it has decided to proceed with its proposal for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The passage of this proposal to this point has been a litany of misjudgments. The statement of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) brings to four his major statements on this proposal. It puts the fourth proposed start-up date, if ever. The very fact that this is now the fourth announcement that we are going to have ATSIC illustrates the level of misjudgment under this Minister in regard to administration of Aboriginal affairs. The legislation was brought into the House on 24 August 1987. It has now been scrutinised by the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, which put forward 40 recommendations for change. Even though these recommendations were substantial, commentators have commented on the disjunction between the evidence and the majority recommendations. In other words, the majority of Committee members did not allow their minds to follow the logic of the evidence. Factional stability required that the Labor majority of the Committee put aside the weight of evidence. It seems that the significant section of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) which opposes this proposal, as we know very well from discussions around the corridors of this Parliament, has decided that it will leave it to the Opposition to try to stop it. The resolution of the disagreement on this issue will now be far more public and damaging than it would have been within the Government.

Today the Minister outlined the Government's response to the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee. In looking at the proposal in its latest revision it is easy to lose sight of the genesis of the proposal, which is now 21 months ago. Three days after the last election, I remind honourable members and the Australian public, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced his new super-portfolio proposal. As part of this arrangement he announced that the Commonwealth Aboriginal affairs bodies would be amalgamated under one statutory authority. Why? What were the reasons given? Was it to promote Aboriginal self-management and input into Commonwealth programs? Was this proposal to replace a tired and worn-out bureaucracy, rife with maladministration? No. Was this a proposal to give Aboriginal people a national voice? No. It was none of these.

The Prime Minister said on that day that it was so that the Australian people broadly would understand the importance that the Government attached to the obligations that government and the community have in this area. It was to be a symbolic gesture, not a considered piece of reform, as argued by this Minister. It was so that the Government could be seen to be doing something, to tide it over the difficulties of the coming Bicentennial, to smooth the waters, to quell the demonstrations. Sure enough, on 10 December when the Minister came into the House and introduced the document Foundations for the Future he described it as `of great and historic importance for all Australians'. The statement was full of generalisations and empty of detail. The very conception of the idea of ATSIC sprang from the Government's bicentennial guilt trip.

There were no administrative reviews requiring a change in Aboriginal administration. The Block Efficiency Scrutiny Unit had rejected any suggestion of joint Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and DAA field services, let alone amalgamation. So the most up-to-date scrutiny report that the Government had in 1987 actually rejected that concept. The first serious airing of the proposal for a statutory commission to replace the Department was within the context of the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration during the 1970s. Whilst Coombs recommended against such a commission, a consultant, C. D. Rowley, suggested that the client to department relationship was inappropriate in Aboriginal affairs. Rowley maintained that in the light of the special claims of Aboriginal people the client to department relationship should be replaced by a bargaining relationship between government and the institute representing the Aboriginal pressure groups. Clearly, the Government's basis of action was the ideology of the 1970s rather than the administrative realities of the 1980s. This ethos of special arrangements based on special claims asserts Aborigines to be a different group of Australian citizens. It is an ethos that gives rise to the separatist policies of the Government, to separate out Aboriginal people from the mainstream of Australian life. In contrast, the coalition asserts that, whilst the Aboriginal people have a special status as the first Australians, all Australians should be treated equally. Aboriginal Australians should be assisted on the basis of need and not on the basis of race.

I want to turn to several points in regard to what the Minister has said. Firstly, there is no difference between separating out economic and welfare functions, and that will be a disastrous situation. Secondly, the Minister has been forced to improve accountability provisions because of the actions of the coalition. Thirdly, confusion still reigns supreme in the proposal before the Parliament, even though amended. The confusion between the representative and executive functions remains. Fourthly, the coalition's position in regard to the Institute of Aboriginal Studies remaining separate has been accepted by the Government, and we welcome that. Fifthly, the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs has been justified. Sixthly, the House has not been given any assurance that the Minister has the interest to ensure that accountability will occur under any revised structure. Seventhly, the Opposition rejects the Prime Minister's assertion that the fundamental problems were with the ADC. Quite frankly, they were with the whole portfolio, and in the Auditor-General's report there are 60 pages on the DAA as well. So we reject that claim by the Prime Minister, and we reject the claim that the coalition is not interested in Aboriginal people being part of the decision making process. That is clearly false and we reject it.

I now turn my attention to the fundamentals of ATSIC as it proposed. The Minister has come in here today and illustrated to the Parliament and the people of Australia that he is just cutting around the edges of this proposal. He has not changed the main thrust of it. The ATSIC proposal rests on a suspect foundation. Worse, however, it is flawed in its detail. What the Minister submitted today was mere renovation work. The fact is that the key plank of ATSIC is cut from sapwood. As this plank is placed in position and begins to take the weight that inevitably it will, the structure will shrink, warp, and inevitably break.

A fundamental need in Aboriginal affairs is accountability. When Minister Hand uses the term in relation to ATSIC he refers to two distinct relationships. When he talks to Aboriginal people he talks of accountability in terms of ATSIC giving them control of the bureaucracy through the election of commissioners. When he talks to the wider community he talks of accountability in terms of the efficiency and effectiveness of administration of Aboriginal affairs. The coalition believes that under ATSIC both aspects will be worse than they are now. The resolution of this conflict is fundamental to the viability of any administration in Aboriginal affairs.

If the Government really wants to get Aboriginal affairs administration back on the track, there is a great need for a return to a bipartisan approach, one which has been rejected by this Government over the last six or eight years. Government members are the ones who broke bipartisanship. The Government ought to go back to the drawing board with this proposal and search for a bipartisan approach to administration of this vital area. The Minister is silent on this major conflict. The reality is that the conflicting interests within the Commission will ultimately force the ATSIC commissioners to choose their constituency. When a large community in a zone needs funding for a project, it will not take a commissioner long to decide that his or her need for votes is greater than the Government's need for sound financial management. To suggest that decisions will be made otherwise denies the democratic process and is contrary to any government's experience in Aboriginal affairs in the last 25 years. One cannot serve two masters. The commissioners will learn that quickly. It is in this conflict that the seeds of the demise of ATSIC are sown and are clearly evident, even before the legislation has passed this Parliament. ATSIC cannot improve, and has not improved, accountability for Commonwealth funds. Today's amendments will make very little progress in that area.
As to the second aspect-that is, the Commonwealth Administration's accountability to Aboriginal people-the ATSIC task force struck the bottom line in a letter to Senator Coulter in which it wrote:

The scheme presents a challenge to the leadership of the Aboriginal community to the extent they provide governments with professional objective advice. They will obtain the opportunity to influence the development of government policy.

If, however, the Aboriginal leadership is unable to recognise the reality that no government will abrogate ultimate responsibility for governing and demands the freedom to operate purely as a lobby group inside government, the Commission will be isolated by the bureaucracy and will lose credibility and influence within government. The bottom line is that the Commission may court two masters but, when the crunch comes, it is the Government which regards itself as the real master. Either the Commission cooperates with the Government, to the detriment of Aboriginal opinion, or it will be isolated from the very source of its power. ATSIC cannot improve accountability to the Aboriginal people. As one Australian Labor Party member of parliament is quoted as saying, ATSIC is either a disaster or a fraud. The Commission will be either an administrative disaster, without tight ministerial oversight, or a fraud on the Aboriginal community, if the Minister enforces the legislation to the letter of the law.

The ATSIC approach of trying to fuse the representative and administrative functions into one organisation will inevitably produce so much unnecessary and destructive friction that the Commission will have little chance of success. Even with separate goals for areas in the portfolio-as we have seen until now, there have been enormous difficulties-what we will see is a confused set of goals for the Commission. We will see even greater difficulty and, I suggest, greater chaos and shambles some time down the track. It is beyond belief that a government could even contemplate putting an experimentally novel administrative structure on the most educationally deprived group in our community-a structure which we would never dream of using ourselves. No compassionate, thoughtful and concerned administrator would do that to the Aboriginal people of Australia.

The coalition also sees great difficulties in the fusing of representative and administrative functions. This means that the proposal goes beyond providing Aborigines with a consultation mechanism and establishes a black power parliament in this nation. There is no doubt that this fusion will be exploited by the radical, politicised elements in the Aboriginal community to obstruct the benefits that should flow to needy Aborigines. They will also use it to undermine this nation's unity. We have a three-tier parliamentary system representing all systems, all people, all citizens, in this country. We should be encouraging Aboriginal Australians to be involved in the main game, the main political process, rather than a separate political arena. Every encouragement and enthusiasm should be given for them to enter into local, State and Federal government.

Further, as a political rather than a consultative arrangement, Aboriginal people are forced to engage in a political process to have their needs addressed. This can only distract energy from addressing basic needs. Energy will be put into developing a political base to make sure that they get the resources they need rather than focusing on developing local Aboriginal self-management to address those needs. The coalition considers that this Government's separatist political approach to Aboriginal self-management is flawed. To enable Aborigines to gain greater control over their own lives and families, the fundamental issue is not how they control the Commonwealth Aboriginal Affairs bureaucracy: the issue is how they can become independent of it. The prime focus of any reorganisation should be on how the Commonwealth can facilitate more Aboriginal families to be independent of government handouts. The best hope for this is by addressing employment needs so that families can stand alone. That should be the goal. To facilitate that goal, education, health and housing must be improved.

The determination of the Prime Minister to establish a single statutory authority responsible for all aspects of Aboriginal affairs did not mean that the new Commission would deal with all aspects of Aboriginal affairs. The bureaucratic empires of other departments were not proposed for takeover. I illustrate the fact that almost $200m involved in employment, education and training areas is not mentioned in regard to this reorganisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—To be precise, $198m. There is no comment in the statement about a State grants program for Aboriginal housing or an Aboriginal arts board. No attempt has been made to explain why ATSIC is not responsible for those areas any more than an explanation as to why one large bureaucratic structure was needed to take over all the elements of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. We have a number of other concerns which we will address in detail as the legislation comes before the House. Some of those concerns are still the electoral system; the regional boundaries as they are presently designed; the definition of `Aboriginal'; and the use of electoral rolls.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's Aboriginal affairs policy has failed miserably. Its policy of symbolism, separatism and perpetual guilt is totally outmoded, out of date and inappropriate for Aboriginal people. The coalition believes in addressing the basic needs instead of symbolism, of having a one people and a one nation approach as distinct from a separatist approach. We reject the concept of the perpetual guilt mentality that the Government shows continually in debates in this House. In 1980 we acknowledged, as a coalition, Aboriginal dispossession and dispersal and now it is time to get on and address those basic, fundamental, difficult areas in Aboriginal affairs-that is, health, housing, education and employment.

One of the great scandals of government administration is the fact that the money earmarked for Aboriginal advancement does not get through the bureaucracy to the people in need. In the last six years the money allocated has been equivalent to over $100,000 for a family of six. The tragic reality is that that money never reached the grass roots. It is this Government's administration that is culpable in that regard. There was the Bonner review and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's inquiry into the situation at Toomelah in northern New South Wales. Both those inquiries addressed the problem of local, Federal and State governments and the gap that existed in the passing of the buck. ATSIC does not address anything in regard to the three tiers of government. So the problems which have been highlighted will still exist. The Bonner report indicated that the communities were serviced by over 40 government agencies. ATSIC will reduce that number to 39. That is the reality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Big deal!

—As the honourable member says, `Big deal!'. There is no mandate for this Government to put ATSIC in place. I just want to return to the issue of an Aboriginal mandate. In Foundations for the Future the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The effective implementation of ATSIC ultimately rests on receiving a positive endorsement from the Aboriginal and Islander community of Australia. The consultation process fell well short of endorsing anything other than a general proposition.

The coalition believes that, if the Government stands by this statement, it should put the proposal to a plebiscite within the Aboriginal community to test the waters, to see whether the Aboriginal Australians believe that this structure is a good one. The Government should put a provision in the Bill so that it will be proclaimed only when it receives the endorsement of the Aboriginal and Islander community by plebiscite. Without such an endorsement the Government cannot claim a mandate.

In conclusion, the proposal for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission still has not been justified by this Government. It is unnecessary and I suggest to this Parliament and to the Australian people that it is culturally inappropriate. The amended proposal that has emerged is still faulty and I regard it as unsafe. If pursued, it will operate to the detriment of the very people it is allegedly designed to serve. It is likely to lead to worse outcomes than those of the bodies it is to replace, to worse services for Aboriginal and Islander people, to less accountability of the Commission and its servants to the Aboriginal and Islander people, and to less accountability to all Australians.

As yet the Government has not made any convincing case justifying the radical changes involved in this proposal. The problems of Aboriginal people are too complex and the links with all aspects of government too diverse for this experiment to have much chance of success. The coalition believes that the amended ATSIC proposal should be withdrawn and the whole concept it represents reconsidered. I hope that the Government will not guillotine the debate in the Senate; that it will allow a sensitive, thoughtful debate about this important issue; and that it will allow the senators time to give detailed consideration to this massive rearrangement which we are opposed to.
