DEBATE.TITLE: ADMINISTRATION OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRSABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION: THE WAY AHEAD

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it would suit the convenience of the House to debate the ministerial statement on the administration of Aboriginal affairs together with the ministerial statement on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission made by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and related papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am somewhat amazed by the contributions of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles). I think they have both presented a tiresome performance. They have demonstrated yet again in this place a lack of credibility, a lack of moral fibre and a lack of preparedness to listen to Aboriginal and Islander Australians. I thought that the contribution by the Leader of the Opposition was particularly pathetic. It was epitomised by a tirade against any concept of self-management by Aboriginal and Islander Australians, it contained empty rhetoric and it made a number of false accusations about the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) misleading this House.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, the Leader of the Opposition had the temerity to praise the work and the contributions of the infamous and, dare I say, despicable senator for the Northern Territory, Grant Tambling. I use those words because I mean them. He is the person who is responsible for creating division in the Northern Territory community in particular and also for fostering division within the Australian community by undermining the confidence of the general community in Aboriginal people throughout Australia by his attacks on Aboriginal Australians and by promoting the concept of a black mafia. He said that he has consulted with Aboriginal people and that he reflects their views. Let me tell honourable members that nothing could be further from the truth. I mix fairly widely with my constituents in the Northern Territory and with Aboriginal and Islander people throughout Australia. Not once have I heard one word in support of the Leader of the Opposition, the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs-the honourable member for Braddon-or that nitwit senator from the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. Some of the language that has been used is not only colourful but also unparliamentary. I ask for a withdrawal of it.
—I will certainly allow that point of order. I ask the honourable member for the Northern Territory to withdraw.
—I will no longer refer to the senator for the Northern Territory as a nitwit.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, that was a deliberate flouting of your ruling and I ask you to call the honourable member to order.

—Order! I point out to the honourable member for the Northern Territory that it is against Standing Orders for any member of this House to cast personal reflections on the character of other members of this Parliament. I ask him to adhere to that ruling and to withdraw the offensive statement.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, in deference to your ruling, I withdraw, but I maintain my view about the senator for the Northern Territory. As a vindication of my view, I will just quote a statement attributed to him in the Centralian Advocate of 3 March 1989. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Senator Grant Tambling has hit back at accusations he did not consult Aborigines about the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.
Combined Aboriginal organisations in Alice Springs and Tennant Creek and the Northern Land Council last week called for Senator Tambling to resign because of his opposition to ATSIC.

What did Senator Tambling say? In true faith with his statements about a black mafia he said that he rejected the claims and labelled them `wild accusations by radical groups'. Who were these radical groups? Among them were the Central Australian Aboriginal Congress, an Aboriginal health organisation whose work has been praised not only by this Government but also by the Opposition and the Northern Territory Government; the Institute for Aboriginal Development, an educational institution in Alice Springs; and Tangentyere Council, a town camp resource agency in Alice Springs. The work of the Tangentyere Council has also been praised by this Government, by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs and by the Northern Territory Government.

Yet these groups are victimised as being radical groups and it has been said that what they say is not representative of Aboriginal views. Let me inform members of the Opposition and the House that they represent Aboriginal opinion, unlike Senator Tambling, unlike the Leader of the Opposition and unlike the shady person from Braddon, who is afraid to venture through the doorways of these Aboriginal organisations as he knows what will happen to him. He knows that his views are not the views of Aboriginal people and he knows that the views that he expresses are those of a minority group within the Australian community. Yet he has the temerity to walk into this House and make accusations about the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that have no foundation in fact and are entirely fictional and he supports the statements that have been made in a disgraceful manner in the Senate and other places about people working in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) or Aboriginal organisations throughout Australia. They have been victimised, vilified and attacked by members of the Opposition, who have done it in a very thoughtful way. Their purpose has been to divide the Australian community, as has been said here today.

We have had the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Braddon, saying that we should return to bipartisanship. When this Government was elected we made that plea for bipartisanship. We have had three debates in this House around the concept of bipartisanship. Not once have honourable members opposite taken up the cudgels of that debate and accepted that approach. They have sought division; that has been their purpose. They have not tried to reconcile the differences which we may have on these issues. I repeat that not once has the Leader of the Opposition, the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, or any other member of the Opposition come up with any constructive suggestions about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) despite the numerous invitations by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. He made those invitations as early as December 1987, yet not once have members of the Opposition approached his office with any valid suggestions either about the administration of Aboriginal affairs generally or, in this particular case, about the ATSIC legislation. Yet they come in here and purport to represent a view which they say has some credibility; it has no credibility.

Aboriginal affairs is in a state of siege because of the complete disregard for any concept of justice, equality or fairness by the Opposition. Members of the Opposition have conducted a witch-hunt which has clear objectives. Those objectives have been to undermine the public confidence and the ability of Aboriginal people to manage their own affairs. That has been their purpose. They do not resile from it because they are saying it. It is part of an ideologically and politically motivated attack to divide the Australian community. They have refused to work in a constructive and meaningful way with the Minister and this Government. They feign support for concepts of self-management and self-determination, but the coalition's wariness of the term `self-determination' or `self-management' is not just a question of semantics. Members of the Opposition do not support it and they have said as much here today. What they want is a mainstream of all activities in the areas of Aboriginal and Islander affairs. Members of the coalition are not prepared to accept that Aboriginal and Islander people may have different expectations, quite legitimate demands, for the recognition of their rights and honourable members opposite will not recognise them. Instead they want to impose their will upon them as they have done in the past.

The coalition agenda has clearly as its basis the removal of any special recognition of Aboriginal rights. Both the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs have said as much today in this House. No longer are they talking about self-management; no longer are they looking at self-determination; and no longer are they prepared to look at the special rights and needs of Aboriginal and Islander Australians. They have thrown that out the window despite being committed to it from as far back as 1973. The agenda they have set is to moderate the behaviour of Aboriginal people to accord with what the coalition believes to be appropriate-not what Aboriginal and Islander people may believe is appropriate or significant, but what the coalition believes is appropriate. This Government has taken a different approach. This Government has said, `We will go to Aboriginal and Islander people and see what they think is most appropriate. We will provide them with the mechanisms to establish the priorities of Aboriginal and Islander affairs in this country', unlike members of the Opposition, who have taken the approach that they will not wear that. What they have said is that they will oppose that at every turn and they have demonstrated that they will do that both here and in the Senate. They oppose any agenda which includes the possibility of a settlement and any sort of reconciliation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians through any treaty or compact. It was rejected here again today by the Leader of the Opposition. Members of the Opposition oppose land rights. They have an agenda which is principally aimed at denying Aboriginal and Islander people the right to develop their own structures, mechanisms and organisations to represent their interests. As I have said, their idea is to stop them from setting their own priorities.

This debate has been about ATSIC. Innuendo and allegations have been made purposely by the Opposition. It has undermined the support for the Aboriginal and Islander people in our community. I would like to read some comments made by a very venerable Australian, Dr Nugget Coombs, in the Age. He was making some observations about the attacks which have been perpetrated by the Opposition principally, I might say in the first instance, through the Senate estimates committee structure. He refers to personal attacks which have been made on Aboriginal and Islander people. He states:

. . . all these lent plausibility to the view that the real agenda of the debate, an agenda shared . . . was not to design an effective political instrument for black-white relationships but to prevent any significant transfer of power to Aborigines. Gerry Hand must go, not because he was doing a bad job, but because the process he had set in train might result in such a transfer.
That is the agenda. He continues:

Furthermore, the debate has left a public image of Aboriginal Affairs as a vast area of failure-not merely within the agencies of the minister's portfolio, but throughout those of Aboriginal communities and their organisations. This image, I believe, is profoundly false.
No-one with any more authority in Australian public administration could make such a statement, but members on the Opposition benches take no note of it. He continues:
True, there are evidences of policy mistakes, administrative incompetence and individual corruption, as there also are in all areas of white Australian affairs.
We need not comment any further about that. He says:
Nevertheless, the overall picture in Aboriginal society is one of increasing effectiveness and a record of success at individual, group and national level, which amounts, I believe, to a renaissance.
What do members of the Opposition want to do with a renaissance? They want to put it in the back cupboard and forget about it. Dr Coombs continues:

In all areas where the outcome depends on individual or collective Aboriginal competence and creativity, example of achievement can be added to example. Those who, for whatever motive, choose to see or present Aboriginal Australians as inevitably heading for failure and despair can think again.

The message is: think again. Aboriginal people are not headed for despair or failure; they will take up the challenge which this Government has put before them and they will do it well. Members of the Opposition were not prepared to give them the credibility to be able to make that effort: instead they want to white-ant the Aboriginal people at the post. As Dr Coombs said, what needs to be recognised in terms of the debate about the reports which have been put down in the Parliament is that they were reports about:
Organisations we-that is non-Aboriginal and Islander Australians-created, embodying our concepts, offering such opportunities and imposing such constraints as we think wise in our interests.

That is the message. The message of the members of the Opposition is that they will only allow Aboriginal people to do what they think is in their interests and not in the Aboriginal people's interests. The attacks which they have made on Aboriginal people, and particularly on the present commissioners of the ADC, are scurrilous because they pay no account to the efforts of the Aboriginal people and other people who have been working with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to try to correct the maladministration that may have occurred in the past-maladministration which, if there is any evidence of it, occurred not when this man was Minister. Most of the material which has arisen in these reports came from a period prior to when this man was Minister, from periods way back when the coalition was on the government benches. But members of the Opposition pay no account whatsoever to that.

Just to illustrate what the Opposition agenda is really all about, I will briefly quote from a statement by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), who is reported to have said in an address to a Port Macquarie rally in July 1984 that `Aboriginal affinity with the land was not much different to the affinity he had with his own property'. That epitomises the sort of attitude the Opposition has. What did John Elliott say? He said in November 1988 at a Liberal Party meeting in Perth that he was against handing over land to Aborigines. He said that the handing over of Ayers Rock to the local Aboriginal population was a national disgrace. There we go. That is the sort of attitude that members of the Opposition have. Yet the shadow Minister, led by the Leader of the Opposition, comes into this place and condemns this Minister and this Government for taking an approach to Aboriginal affairs which will dramatically alter the balance of relationships between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal and Islander Australians. It is quite a deliberate exercise to transfer power back to Aboriginal and Islander Australians, to give them the responsibility for making decisions, to give them the ability to manage their own affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has elapsed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard this afternoon two or three speeches from Government members which have said very little. In fact, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) were to speak, I guess members on this side of the House and the Australian people were expecting something a little special to be said. The Prime Minister and the Minister have promised virtually everything but delivered nothing, as they have done in the area of Aboriginal policy in the last six years. There was nothing new in what they said, with the exception that they will go ahead with the disastrous Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation, which nobody, except a few Government members, seems to want. I find that quite remarkable.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of Aboriginal affairs in the last six years is a history of chaos, maladministration and embarrassment to taxpayers and Aboriginal people. Little more has been achieved than the discrediting of the Aboriginal community in its own eyes and in the eyes of the public. To a large extent Aboriginal people's hopes have been dashed, and it appears from the statements by the Minister and the Prime Minister that their hopes will continue to be dashed.

The Prime Minister has acted in a quite cynical and blatant manner in regard to Aboriginal affairs. He tries to use the Aboriginal community in an attempt to win votes. We see him on Sunday night television programs. He flies into some distant Aboriginal community and swans around, exuberating in an affected concern for Aboriginal people. He ends up making a lot of ridiculous promises such as treaties, et cetera, and raises unreal expectations amongst Aboriginal people. Then he flies out, leaving the Minister to pick up the pieces. Unfortunately, the Prime Minister usually leaves behind him more chaos, and more dashed hopes than when he arrived. It is a cruel and ruthless exercise to have been perpetrated in the last few years. It is not washing with the Aboriginal people at all. They are seeing through this insincerity. The way the Prime Minister is acting in this regard is becoming a bit of a joke amongst the rest of Australia.

While all this is going on we have continual reports in the press of money being wasted on poker machines or training racehorses or not being spent on projects that it was supposed to be spent on, of hotels going broke, and so on. I ask the Government: What is the result of all this? At the end of it the average Australian, the average Aborigine, can see only waste, corruption and desperation. We are seeing these things in a magnitude that has never been seen before. I acknowledge that there have always been problems in this area, but they seem to have been getting quite a deal worse over the last five or six years. Any number of reports have been prepared concerning this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had your chance to put it up at the inquiry. You never put a thing up.

—The latest report, the Auditor-General's report, verifies that the problems have been worsening. Paragraph after paragraph tells of waste and mismanagement. When the Minister, who is so vocal in the chamber at the moment, is asked about this in Question Time his answer is: `I am aware of the problem. It has existed for a long time. We are looking into it. We are doing the best we can. We are consulting the Aboriginal people'. I suppose that in one sense that is a fair enough answer, but it seems to be the answer we are getting to every question we ask. The Australian people are getting a bit tired of it. They expect a little more.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a background of chaos, of shambles, of multiple investigations. Instead of straightening out the problem or doing something towards solving it, the Minister is giving us the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. ATSIC will only exacerbate the situation. It will cost a lot of money. It will divide the Aboriginal community, as it is already doing. It will certainly divide the Australian community. The amazing thing is that the Aboriginals themselves do not want ATSIC. If the Minister is so confident that he has consulted the Aborigines sufficiently and that the Aborigines want ATSIC, I invite him, as did the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), to hold a poll, a referendum, to see what the Aboriginal people really want.

Instead, the Prime Minister and the Minister got up today and reaffirmed that the Government will go ahead with ATSIC, come what may. I find that amazing, particularly in light of inquiries such as the Senate one, which found an enormous number of deficiencies in the original Bill. In fact, I would go so far as to say that most Government members see this legislation as a noose hovering over their heads, about to be slipped around their necks before the election. Most of them, from what I hear, would love to be rid of it. They would like to see the last of ATSIC. They would like to see it go away, disappear. Instead, I repeat, the Prime Minister got up today and told us nothing new at all, except that he was going to maintain his support of the Minister and the left wing who, for some reason, so desperately want to see this legislation implemented.

What of the Minister's speech itself? He revealed nothing more than a blind ideological obsession, a blind left wing commitment to this socialist Taj Mahal, the ATSIC legislation. He said that, come what may, the Government will go ahead with it. It will set up a system of regional councils. It will set up a commission replacing the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. It will appoint the commissioners. In other words, as the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs said, the Government will set up a type of black parliament in Australia as soon as it can. I find it absolutely incredible.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true and you know it. I don't mind you coming in to have a go but why don't you tell the truth? That is not the case. Get it right. Read the legislation, you fool.

—I have read the original legislation, which was incredibly defective. The Minister seems to be quite hysterical about this. As I have said, I read the original legislation. We pointed out errors in it. It went before a Senate committee, an all-party committee, which agreed with us that the legislation was full of errors. And the Minister says, `Read the legislation'. We look forward to seeing the next lot of legislation. If it is anything like the last, it will be blocked, too. I can assure the Minister of that. Aboriginals themselves do not want it. It will do nothing more nor less than divide Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister ran around earlier this year consulting various groups. I am told that he handed out in excess of $800,000 in goodies, four-wheel drive vehicles and goodness knows what, trying to get some approval for ATSIC. For most of the areas he went to he had no maps. Aborigines are complaining that there was no detail, that at best they got only a general concept of what was going on. I acknowledge to the Minister that there are problems in explaining something as complex as this to Aboriginal people, but apparently the Minister's attempt was very much a half-hearted one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll tell you what; it is difficult, all right. You cannot understand. You are the only one having any difficulty with it.

—The Minister has gone hysterical in the chamber again. He is walking around the House, shouting and screaming as I am trying to speak. I am telling him what Aboriginal people say. If he does not believe me, let me read out a letter from one of the Aboriginal people. The letter, written to the Minister by a member of the Anmatjara tribe of Central Australia, states:

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard about this new proposal for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissioner. We went to see Mr Hand and Yuendumu but he was gone. He only stay a short time. That no good. He should stay longer and listen to each group and not just visit big communities.

There was a meeting at Three Bore near Utopia. We heard Alan Randall talk about ATSIC. We heard about those new zones, voting for the Commission and all those things. We had a big talk about it between ourselves when we came home. We are not happy with ATSIC.
Other mobs we talk to are not happy with ATSIC either. All over Napperby, Alyawarra, Utopia outstations, we don't like to mix everyone up in one big council.
We got map today from D.A.A. The map shows all those ATSIC regions in different colours.

Well now we got to tell you, we are not happy about ATSIC and we are not happy about that map. That map is wrong. You can't split our country up. You can't put us with all those other people from different country. That mob from south haven't got skin groups like us. You can't put us with them.
We are not happy with ATSIC and we don't want it.
We are going to talk more about this with our own people.

That is the sort of consultation which has gone on. It was only recently that the Aboriginal people heard about this legislation for the first time. They want time to discuss it, and that seems to me to be not an unreasonable request, for heaven's sake!

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling wrote the letter; I'll bet he did.

—The member for Leichhardt is shouting out, `Senator Tambling wrote that letter; I'll bet he did'. I will check that assertion later and see who is correct. The Government is nothing but hell-bent on ramming ATSIC down the throats of the Aboriginal people.
—Splitting Australia.

—It is splitting Australia, as the honourable member for Cowper says. Nobody wants the ATSIC legislation-Australians do not want it; the Aboriginals do not want it. The Government is too terrified to have a poll. I find that extraordinary. I believe it is patronising to Aborigines for the Government to do this to them. The legislation will not work because it is not the Aboriginal way of doing things. The Government does not seem to be able to grasp this simple point. The Minister has set himself up as someone who is going to tell the Aboriginal community what he thinks is best for it and it is going to cop it or else; that is all there is to it. The amount of consultation with the Aboriginal people will be minuscule indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen other things which have gone on in relation to the Government's trying to get this piece of legislation implemented. For example, when the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) commissioners protested about ATSIC, saying they wanted further time to consider it, and finally would not accept it, what happened? The entire board of the ADC was sacked. Then we saw the amazing event of the Government trying to smear the board with a fictitious story of financial mismanagement, which was leaked to one of the major newspapers in the country. That act, quite frankly, was disgraceful and I was sorry to see that the Government had to resort to that action to try to get acceptance for this legislation which nobody wants.

The Minister has ignored the problem. He is ignoring the concern in the community about various aspects of this legislation, but he is still telling us that it will go ahead. Regardless of what one looks at in the legislation, nobody seems to agree with it. For example, there is a section relating to voting. In his speech today, the Minister said that there would be voluntary enrolment for regional council elections-voluntary enrolment-but compulsory voting for those who did enrol. Anybody who knows anything about the history of Aboriginal organisations in Australia knows immediately that that is a prescription for absolute disaster. It will allow coercion immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. The honourable member is misinterpreting what I said in that speech.
—That is not a point of order.
—The reference the honourable member made is to a Senate recommendation, not what I said I was going to do. He could at least read my speech correctly.
—There is no point of order.
—On a further page the Minister says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has given careful thought to voting systems. In its view the over-riding consideration is that a public roll based on race, whatever its purpose, should not be established in this country.

We are going to have an election in this country based on race, based on the colour of a person's skin. Yet these people are not going to have a roll based on race. Will the Minister now jump up and take a point of order and say that that is not in his speech? I find that an absolute contradiction.

There is so much which is objectionable, but unfortunately there is so little detail in the Bill. It tells one nothing; it simply states that the Government will go ahead with the legislation and will have this shonky voting system. Wherever there is a scintilla of detail, the coalition finds itself in total objection to it. We find the whole proposal quite objectionable. There has been nothing new offered today which will change the Opposition decision to oppose the original legislation that came before the Parliament. The Opposition urges all members in this chamber to vote according to their consciences and reject the legislation when it finally comes before the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to enter this debate, following the ministerial statements delivered earlier today by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). These statements follow the debate raised by the Opposition late last week in relation to Aboriginal administration. This debate was raised in a sequence of many Opposition objections to Aboriginal issues and many criticisms of the present Minister, in relation to Aboriginal matters. Honourable members have come in here, day after day, week after week, month after month-in fact, it has been some 16 months since the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs first outlined Foundations for the Future, which included reference to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). For some 16 months now we have heard those opposite condemn and decry the efforts of the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in improving the lot of the Aboriginal person and the Aboriginal race.

SPEECH.PARA: One finds it a little disheartening, to say the least, that after 16 months not one positive contribution has been made by those sitting opposite. It is at least refreshing to hear the statements made by the Prime Minister and the Minister today relating to the administration of Aboriginal affairs and ATSIC. I believe the statements were timely. It is important that these issues be resolved, not solely to allow the passage of the legislation through Parliament, but also, very importantly, to place clearly on the record this Government's attitude to the administration of Aboriginal affairs; a position which is clear, unequivocal and in stark contrast to the attitude and policies of those opposite.

Only last week, during a debate on a matter of public importance, a considerable number of these issues was canvassed. I do not intend to go over those issues. On that occasion, I appealed to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to indicate his Party's policies to the Aboriginal people of our nation and, more importantly, to rein in some of the more irresponsible members of the Opposition in their attitudes and comments in relation to Aboriginal matters generally. That is a step that has to be taken urgently by the Leader of the Opposition.

The sad history of the discussions and debate on Aboriginal matters since the Hawke Government came to office reflects adversely the attitude of the Opposition. As I have said previously, we have had no positive input from those opposite over a long period. The sole approach-I repeat, their sole approach-has been one of disruption, diversion and blind opposition to any suggestion of change; change which we, on this side of the House, believe will be in the best interests of the Aboriginal people of our nation.

I think it is a sad reflection that history will record that those opposite have opposed any issue of change in Aboriginal matters, but on no occasion have we heard any proffering of alternatives from the Opposition. It will go down as a sad chapter in the history of the Australian nation that those opposite have engaged in total and abstract opposition to any matters raised in relation to Aboriginal issues.

In December of 1987, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs made a significant statement in this place relating to Aboriginal issues. In prefacing his summary, he made observations that should be known to most Australians, but unfortunately, they are not. He spoke of a period of more than 40,000 years during which the Aboriginal and Islander people had considered themselves the custodians of this land. He spoke of the maintenance of their pride, dignity and integrity, despite the impact of European settlement just some 200 years ago, and the subsequent dispossession of their land by European settlers, an impact which is still being felt by Aboriginal and Islander people. On that occasion the Minister also made reference to the fact that only 20 years ago the Australian people voted overwhelmingly in a referendum to give the Commonwealth the power to make laws affecting the lives of those Aboriginal and Islander people. It was on this premise that the Government acknowledged that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people were prior occupiers and the original owners of this land, something that was acknowledged in a resolution passed in this House-once again, not on a bipartisan basis-on 23 August 1988.

The resolution that acknowledged the prior occupation by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders thousands of years before British settlement at Sydney Cove on 26 January 1788 also acknowledged that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders suffered dispossession and dispersal of their traditional lands by the British Crown. In doing so, the Government affirmed the importance of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders' culture and heritage and, importantly, the entitlement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders to self-management and self-determination.

On the occasion of speaking on the resolution the Prime Minister made reference to the many programs of assistance to Aboriginal and Islander people decided upon by governments without informed involvement by the people they were designed to assist. This fundamental flaw in Aboriginal administration is to be removed. I believe that the introduction of the ATSIC legislation will achieve that goal.

The attitude of those opposite in relation to the ATSIC legislation has been one of diversion and disruption. There has been a total lack of understanding, whether deliberate or not, in relation to those matters. Unfortunately, those opposite have not in a spirit of bipartisanship put up any positive alternatives. We have had the sorry state of members of the Opposition parading around the nation misrepresenting to Aboriginal people and communities the thrust and purpose of the ATSIC legislation. None of the public statements by those irresponsible members-I do not class everyone opposite in that category-have been revoked, unfortunately, or disclaimed by the Leader of the Opposition or his shadow spokesman on Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles). In those circumstances we must then accept that the Leader of the Opposition embraces the comments of those such as Senator Sheil-I will not go into the nasty detail of what he has said over a period-Senator Boswell in his untruthful utterances throughout the State of Queensland, and Senator Stone; the list goes on. It includes members of the Liberal Party, such as the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). It is no wonder that the Aboriginal people of this nation have become disheartened and are now disillusioned with the approach to issues affecting them taken by members of this Parliament. That disheartenment and disillusionment could only be expected in all the circumstances.

In August of last year Senator Sheil spoke of `black bludgers and stirrers looting the nation'. He is on the record as having said it. As I have said previously, neither the Leader of the Opposition nor the shadow spokesman on Aboriginal affairs has denied or refuted that. So what are we to believe? Does the Leader of the Opposition allow irresponsible members of his back bench to go about this country dividing the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people of this nation? Why does he not act? One can only assume that he accepts the statements made by those whom I described as irresponsible members of his back bench. It is unfortunate that Senator Sheil has a long and disgraceful record with respect to making racial remarks, but his more recent outbursts have gone unchecked. It is a shame that action such as that taken by the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, was not taken when these outrageous outbursts became public.

Almost a year and a half ago the ATSIC legislation was foreshadowed by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Notwithstanding that period of time, the legislation has not passed the Parliament, even though consultation never before contemplated in relation to an Act of parliament has taken place between the Government and the Aboriginal people of this nation. It is interesting to note that the response to the legislation by Aboriginal people has generally been positive. I do not accept the assertions of those opposite that the Aboriginal people generally are opposed to the ATSIC legislation. I have travelled far and wide through Queensland and the Northern Territory-indeed, throughout this nation-and if one thing is certain in my mind it is that in general the Aboriginal people of this nation accept in principle the ATSIC legislation.

To be a little more precise, when bodies such as the Aboriginal Coordinating Council, which represents all Aboriginal communities in Queensland, and the Torres Strait Island Coordinating Council, which represents all the islander communities in Queensland, support the legislation strongly and strenuously, I have some difficulty in accepting the assertion of those opposite that it is not accepted within the Aboriginal community. There is a feeling within Aboriginal communities of frustration and despair. The blame for such frustration and despair lies squarely at the doors of the Leader of the Opposition and his spokesman on Aboriginal affairs.

As I have done in the past, I repeat my appeal to the Leader of the Opposition to take a bipartisan approach to Aboriginal issues so that the government of the day, whatever its political persuasion, can get on with the important role of introducing the legislation and measures which will benefit that underprivileged sector of our community. To continue the negative approach of the Opposition will only delay the flow of those benefits to the Aboriginal people, not just in the area of administration but also, more importantly, in the areas of health, education, employment and other basics that normally others in our community take for granted.

The Prime Minister and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs have already spoken of the Government report on the findings of the Auditor-General in his report on the Aboriginal Development Commission and Department. Already the Government has acted and will continue to act to overcome the deficiencies highlighted in the report. In a determined approach to overcome these deficiencies, no good or proper purpose will be served by those opposite, particularly the shadow spokesman, coming into this place day after day criticising and deriding by inference the Aboriginal people and their organisations in their endeavours towards self-management and self-determination. I conclude on a sad note. Being mindful of the approaching election, I have no doubt that these attacks by the Opposition on the Aboriginal people and their organisations will continue. I have no doubt that in those criticisms and public denouncements of those opposite we will not hear any positive alternatives or utterances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to take part in the debate on the ministerial statements on the administration of Aboriginal affairs and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission presented by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) respectively, I put on record the fact that, whilst I may be very critical of the Minister and some areas of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs I could say some positive things about many areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to comment on a couple of remarks made by the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) when he mentioned Senator Sheil. He talked about Senator Sheil's disparaging description of some Aboriginals as `black bludgers' and so on. If he really understood Senator Sheil's true thinking and looked at his outlook on the Australian population as a whole, he would realise that Senator Sheil says the same things about white bludgers, perhaps in even stronger terms. The honourable member is putting a slant on Senator Sheil's remarks which is undeserved.

The central problems before the House today concern the political and managerial incompetence of the Hawke Government in Aboriginal affairs and the impact and consequences of that incompetence on the Department, on the Aboriginal community and on parliamentary and ministerial practice. Let us be quite clear about the fourfold consequences. First, there is the corruption and demoralisation of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. That is a fact. Secondly, there is the alienation of large sections of the Aboriginal community. Thirdly, there is the discrediting of the difficult long term work of Aboriginal development in the eyes of the taxpayers of Australia and in the eyes of Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people. Fourthly, there is the contemptuous discarding of traditional practices of ministerial accountability in this Parliament.

I wish to take issue with specific sections of the statements of both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs before I make general comments on this unfortunate and harmful course of events in the area of Aboriginal affairs. My first point concerns paragraph 2 on page 3 of the Prime Minister's statement. This ingenious paragraph is designed to suggest an acceptance of responsibility for the mismanagement of policy, administration, funding and accountability which has clearly occurred, whereas in actual fact the opposite is the case. The Prime Minister accepts the responsibility for future unspecified change, but not for the crisis which has produced the need for change. To do so, of course, would involve the honourable resignation of the Minister. For all the lip service paid by this Government to the Parliament and to accountability, its commitment to and respect for ministerial responsibility stops short of actually resigning when that is obviously appropriate. The Prime Minister's stance reflects that of the Minister.

Throughout this issue, over the last six months, the Minister has adopted the political approach of implying that he is as angry and determined to turn things around as are the coalition and the Aboriginal victims of mismanagement. The broader community is also certainly desirous of doing that. That approach has involved the implicit acknow- ledgement that this mess was caused by his predecessor, Minister Holding.

But let us be clear about this Minister's direct responsibility. Yes, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs was brought down in chaos under his predecessor and most of the problems in maladministration predate his appointment in July 1987. The point is that the present Minister was fully aware of the problems, but was either unable or unwilling to tackle them. The facts are that the Minister was active in the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs for four years prior to ministerial appointment. He was aware of the call in a report in 1985 by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure for a judicial inquiry into the Aboriginal Development Corporation (ADC) and apparent malpractice and illegality within the portfolio. In July 1987, when he took up his Ministry, the respected Aboriginal leader, Margaret Valadian, was publicly complaining that her organisation's focus on the need for professional performance and the need for accountability in Aboriginal Affairs was anathema to his Department. He was aware of the problems in July 1987. He has been the Minister for 18 months. He cannot honestly ask us to believe that he is not responsible for the situation in the portfolio in 1989.

I refer to page 9, paragraph 6, of the Prime Minister's statement. The Prime Minister prides himself on the `extraordinary detailed scrutiny' and `wealth of material and analysis' produced by special inquiries over a `relatively short time frame'. The question is this: Why did this Minister not produce this detailed analysis in the same time frame when he became Minister nearly two years ago? That he did not is sufficient grounds for his removal. I simply remind the House that illegal activity, and policy described by an external audit as `out of date, irrelevant, unmeasurable, and unrealistic', characterise this Minister's portfolio, notwithstanding his long-standing familiarity with the portfolio and nearly two years as Minister.

I refer now to those paragraphs on pages 4 and 5 of the Prime Minister's statement where he wants this place to believe that the problems in Aboriginal affairs are inherent in the balancing of self-management and ministerial accountability. I also refer to page 24, paragraph 2, of Minister Hand's statement where he claims that the coalition cannot accept that the Aboriginal people must be part of Government processes, be decision-makers and determine their interests and needs. The coalition would be happy to compare the commitment to, and the success in winning, community support for Aboriginal self-management and self-determination of Ministers Peter Baume and Chaney with that of Ministers Holding and Hand. The comparisons would be more than embarrassing for the Government.

The coalition's record speaks for itself in terms of the achievements of the Fraser Government on land rights, economic development and self-determination. As to accountability and self-management, contrary to the Prime Minister's belief, the two are compatible. The coalition does not share the paternalism and inverse racism of the Government concerning goals set for and by Aborigines in their communities or in the portfolio bureaucracy. We treat Aborigines equally. We assume competence; we expect accountability. I simply refer again to Margaret Valadian, who said in July 1987 as Minister Hand took office:
. . . there is a widely held view that as Aborigines we should be above accountability, but this is an insult to our intelligence.

The coalition understands that there will be mistakes and losses in Aboriginal development. That the Prime Minister can quote Senator Chaney, when he was Minister, on the element of risk is a refutation of Minister Hand's dishonest description of motive and stance on this side.

Finally, I refer to the attempt by the Prime Minister and the Minister to blame the coalition for a politicisation of this issue. The question is: who is responsible for this damaging political exercise? Is it the Opposition, which is duty bound to raise publicly questions concerning abuse of public office and taxpayers' funds and to raise the question of opportunity costs for Aboriginal communities? Or is it the Government, whose incompetence produced the situation and whose refusal to acknowledge the problem and attempts to cover up and to kill the issue have forced the matter to be raised publicly in this manner?

My final comments have to do with the Minister's announcement today that he will press ahead with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). Part of the problem in Aboriginal affairs over the last two years has been this Minister's total preoccupation with his political model of modernisation of the Aboriginal people, his `top-down' revolution designed to create the Aboriginal people. It is an attempt to impose a model of political development designed by one faction of the developing intellectual elite within Aboriginal communities with the political support of the Minister. It deludes its authors who cannot see that fine constitutions and political rhetoric are not the substitute for action to lift life standards and opportunities for Aboriginal communities oppressed by poverty, racism and powerlessness. It is a centralist's fantasy. It will not work. It might damage Aboriginal development by giving politics pride of place instead of equal place with training, education and development on the agenda of Aboriginal people.

I simply say to the Minister that he ought to think hard again about this whole issue. Bipartisanship could be restored and the damage to Aboriginal affairs repaired if he would give up the theatre of treaty and political modelling and discuss long term strategies for Aboriginal development with the coalition and the community, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal.

More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition raises this matter of very great public importance in the context of a statement to be made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tomorrow night on the economic management of this country. I do not think there is any doubt that tomorrow night will be a tragedy as we see this Government basically sell Australia down the economic drain. Tomorrow night's statement will be a blatant political ploy to buy some votes, at the sacrifice of the economy of this country, simply to save the political necks of Government members. That is the harsh reality. I say to honourable members opposite that they will rue the day that the Treasurer brings down this statement. As we look at the conduct of parliamentary business this week we note that the Treasurer has a very simple strategy. It is a strategy that I am sure honourable members opposite can well understand-a strategy to divert attention from the calamity of the Treasurer's Budget strategy for 1988-89. His wages policy is in tatters and I think most people in this Parliament well understand that fact.

SPEECH.PARA: I take as a case study of the sensitivity of the Treasurer to the collapse of his wages policy the finale of the award restructuring package presented by Mr Kelty, which was the negotiations on supplementary payments. What has happened on supplementary payments is a case study of the way in which this Government is dictated to by the trade union movement in the running of economic policy. Yesterday in this House we saw an element of sensitivity on the part of the Treasurer about his conduct of policy, a sensitivity which finds its origins in the debate between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) over supplementary payments.

Some press reports a week or so ago suggested that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris), who is at the table, had some problems about supplementary payments. For the benefit of those not close to the action let me say that supplementary payments for Mr Kelty are the piece de resistance of his wages policy. Mr Kelty is a shrewd customer when it comes to the political scene and one thing that he understands is that politically this Government is going down the gurgler. The last thing that he wants to be associated with is a government that is on its way out. So he has a twofold strategy, and part of that strategy is to shore up his own position. We have seen the exit of the gentrified Mr Crean and heard the ACTU talking about running a public relations campaign to improve its image. We have seen Mr Kelty appeasing the Left and Mr Campbell with the across the board components of award restructuring and we have seen Mr Martin Ferguson, who is much more acceptable to the rank and file, being elevated to the top spot in the trade union movement. So supplementary payments and the proposal which contains them-in other words, across the board wage increases-are very important to Mr Kelty's long term future and, as he sees it, the authority of the ACTU.

Mr Kelty's position on wages policy since the ACTU Executive accepted his propositions at the end of 1988 is that the unions want the lot. There is no halfway house; there is no compromise. In the words of Mr Ferguson, the incoming President, it is pay-back time for the trade union movement. The Minister for Industrial Relations knows, as most commentators know, that supplementary payments, rather than being good news for the low paid, are bad news for them. Supplementary payments are given across the board, regardless of the capacity, the productivity, of enterprises to fund those increases. Have we not seen that in this country before? It is the dog chasing its tail. This is just another round of inflation, more tax increases, bracket increases and the like.

That was the departmental advice that the Minister for Industrial Relations had, and he started to voice that opinion. But interestingly enough, Mr Kelty, in his attack on the Government through the Australian Financial Review, declared the Minister to be incompetent and put the pressure on the Treasurer to come in and save the Kelty deal. I think the Treasurer is peeved because he has had his own Minister for Industrial Relations promoting the position that the Opposition has been putting on supplementary payments, which we oppose. The Minister has had to put that position to the Treasurer, who has known that the Minister was right, as he has known that the departmental advice from a number of senior people in their opposition to supplementary payments was right. But when it came to the crunch, the Treasurer had no choice as he saw it but to capitulate to the ACTU, so he delivered what Mr Kelty required of him. That, quite frankly, is the same for each and every component of award restructuring and the debate that has been going on in recent months. Mr Kelty made clear what he wanted and he has been busily getting it. He has got the lot and that is what honourable members will see tomorrow night-a final, total humiliation for the Treasurer in the conduct of wages policy. We will have, as we now have in this country, the twin evils.

The Treasurer claims that he is running a good wages policy. Let me compare his wages policy with those of other members of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD). The Treasurer is running the worst wages policy in the OECD. Unit labour costs in Australia in 1988 were higher than those in any other member country of the OECD. The rate of inflation in this country is near the top of the tree. This country has the worst of both possible worlds, and it is this Government's wages policy that has brought the country to this very sorry plight. Underpinning all this is what I call Labour's yawning productivity gap. If one looks at productivity figures and compares how Australians are working and how efficiently they are producing with how people in other OECD countries are working and producing, one sees that this nation is going backwards. The productivity figures supplied by the OECD show Australia's position at minus 0.2 per cent. It is no wonder that living standards in this country are falling when productivity is falling. Let us look in comparison at our international competitors. Not only are they in the black, with positive rates of growth in productivity, but they are actually on the move upwards. They have a growth factor. So we have Labor's yawning productivity gap.

Tomorrow night we will hear a statement which will confirm the Government's capitulation to the ACTU, the total humiliation of the Treasurer and a recipe for further inflation and further erosion of international competitiveness. This country will have a short term boost to domestic demand, which is totally irresponsible in the current economic climate. It will have tax cuts unfunded by spending cuts and wage rises across the board unrelated to productivity. I do not think there is much doubt now that almost certainly this will lead to recessionary circumstances. The people most vulnerable to this downturn are those for whom the Treasurer and the Secretary of the ACTU cry crocodile tears in their promotion of supplementary payments. It is not just the Opposition which has this feeling of foreboding about the statement. I draw honourable members' attention to a statement by the leading employer organisation in Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry:
The Australian economy is on course for major economic upheaval sometime during 1990. The policies that are now being followed will potentially stop the economy in its tracks.

That is what we face tomorrow night. The Government has totally endorsed the ACTU's blueprint in the face of very serious reservations by its advisers and a number of leading commentators around Australia. Mr Kelty's blueprint is exactly what we do not need in Australia. We do not need wage rises unrelated to productivity. That is the great cruel hoax of tomorrow night-this illusion that people will be better off, when the advisers, the experts and all those who follows this closely know that people will not be better off; they will be worse off. The Government has had its hands in people's pockets and all they will get back from the tax cuts is a few dollars of what the Government has already taken. Inflation will get the rest. If people still reckon they have a chance of getting ahead, they can be sure of one thing, and that is that increasing levels of taxation will soon get them. The gains will be an illusion only.

The blueprint, instead of giving us a mechanism for increasing productivity, doing things better, giving people an incentive, leads to a very limited agenda for change. Mr Kelty has got things just as he wants them. The Minister is not prepared to stand up to the ACTU and demand working time arrangements, contracting out and all the other sorts of things which would provide people with some chance for real wages growth. We have a more regulated and compressed system as a result of the implementation of Mr Kelty's plan than we have ever had in this country. Instead of a more flexible, less rigid system, we will have a more centralised system. Mr Kelty has been dreaming about this plan since 1970, apparently. Part of his plan is to set in concrete new relativities between key minimum rate awards. As we all know, that is absolutely wrong in terms of providing the greater flexibility we need in the management of our economy.

Instead of leading to improvements for people, we will have a greater institutionalisation of those factors which, I might say, perversely encourage wage break-outs. The Treasurer's sole position this week is that the best form of offence is defence. It is his wages policy which will lead to wage break-outs. The only thing in Australia is that we do not call them wage break-outs when they have been endorsed by an agreement between Mr Kelty and the Treasurer. They are said to be part of the accord; therefore, all will be well. What we need in this country is some real addressing of the problems which have led to wage break-outs in the past. We have had them before in 1974 and 1981.

As we go into the next election the coalition presents two things to the electorate in terms of labour market reform: firstly, a comprehensive policy of labour market reform and, secondly, a wages policy which will end up giving people some real dollars in their pockets to meet some of the ever-increasing costs they have had in recent years. It will really give people a chance to claw their way back from the decline in living standards which has been foisted upon them by the Government as a result of its economic mismanagement. Unlike the Treasurer, we have a comprehensive strategy for reform of the industrial relations system. He is in a corner and he knows it. His problem is that he cannot address these fundamental issues because he is told what he can and cannot do by the ACTU. He has a political blockage in terms of his reliance on the ACTU. For that reason, as he well knows and as the Minister for Industrial Relations knows on the question of supplementary payments as a recent case study, he is in a corner and has nowhere to go.

We say that we ought to address some of the basic institutional factors which have led to unreasonable wage demands in the past. We ought to do something about the imbalance of bargaining power which so characterises industrial relations in this country. Twenty years ago Clarrie O'Shea was let out and, since then, we have had a one-sided industrial relations system. The one side says simply that if it does not get what it wants out of the Industrial Relations Commission it will go out into the field and get it. We have not had a system of effective dispute settling which would impose a proper, sensible regime on people. We also have an award structure that ensures a flow-on of wage increases regardless of the circumstances of a particular enterprise. That is an absolute recipe for across the board wage increases, to the detriment of people because they are unfunded. Our multi-employer awards situation also leads to that fact.

For the Treasurer there is no alternative. He has a policy position constrained by his masters at the ACTU. It is time for Australia to look for a change in direction, for some real reform in industrial relations. Tomorrow night will simply be an example of this Government's being prepared to pay any price for its own political neck, at the sacrifice of the good economic management of this country. The only consolation for the Australian electorate is that it will be able to cast the final judgment on this Government when the next election arrives.

The decision to use labour rather than capital is a rational business decision. It does not mean that business profitability has been reduced. The profit share is now back to appropriate historical levels and that improvement has supported the huge boom in investment that we are witnessing at the moment. Similarly, productivity data are distorted by growth in non-market sectors of the economy and the services sector, and output for those sectors is often measured by input, thus making productivity growth zero even though those sectors have become much more productive. TALK.START.PARA: —But you got rolled by Keating and Kelty.

It is being bullied and dictated to by the union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: Have members of the Opposition ever wondered why the union movement is so influential in dictating this Government's policies? If we want to answer that question, we need look only at some of the people who make up the front bench of the Labor Party which forms this Government at present. If we begin at the most senior of positions, we realise just what sort of an influence the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the union movement have on this Government, commencing with the most senior of positions, that of Prime Minister. Just last week we saw another example of how that occurs. Into Canberra rolled the ACTU team with Mr Kelty at the helm. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Industrial Relations, the Treasurer and Mr Kelty and his team arrived for a big meeting which was held in Canberra. What came out of that meeting? A decision that we are going to have a wage rise, not the wage rise option that the Government wanted, but the wage rise option that the ACTU wanted, that the ACTU dictated to the Government it must have because it is the influence that dictates the policy of the people who govern this country. It is that dictation of policy that concerns us on this side of the House and, indeed, concerns people right throughout Australia. It causes us to believe that it is not in the national interest to have it continue.

We just saw the example of the wage-tax deal struck here last week in Canberra. Last week we also saw the Inter-State Commission bring down its report on the waterfront. Immediately the intellectual giants in some sectors of the trade union movement stepped forward and offered their opinions. People such as Tas Bull stated, `We are not going to have any recommendations put forward by the Inter-State Commission. We are not going to have any of that. There will be no discussions and no negotiations. Any changes will take place over my dead body'. Despite the fact that the recommendations highlight to the people that there could be more than $800m per year in benefits flowing to the people of this country if those recommendations are picked up, we do not hear the Government attack Mr Tas Bull and his colleagues and say, `Look, you are not taking the national interest into account here. There is $800m worth of benefits to be had for the people if changes are made. How about taking that into consideration?'. There is no criticism from the Government in regard to that. Honourable members opposite just sit back in the corner sucking their thumbs and letting the unions dictate the policy. I can bet my boots that we will find within a few months that all the recommendations of that Commission will slowly collect dust in the office of the Minister for Industrial Relations because the issue will not be raised again. All of those matters cause us concern.

Why is concern being expressed not just on this side of the House but throughout the community? We are concerned and we feel the need for change when we look at the economy. The economy is in dire peril. We have the biggest balance of payments deficit this country has ever experienced. We have rising interest rates. Mortgage rates are at the highest they have ever been. We have tax rates that are increasing. People are paying more taxes than they have ever paid before. Our standards of living are falling. This is well recognised. Why? It is because this Government will not bring this country into line with what the rest of the world is doing to ensure that we have a vibrant economy and a future that we can depend upon that will be prosperous. Why will the Government not do something? It is because the unions dictate what this country does, because the unions are the government. It is because the unions are made up of people who pull the strings here in Canberra. Until that is changed, then I am afraid we will not see the status quo changed.

The unions are not radical; the unions stand for no change; the unions stand for status quo. Any change such as the change the honourable member for Flinders, our shadow Minister for industrial relations, is proposing would actually reduce the power that the trade union movements have. The situation occurring in Australia today has caused us on this side of the House and people right throughout Australia to bring to the attention of the Government the need for change. On the Opposition side of politics I have responsibility for tourism. There is no greater need for change than in the area of award rates, penalty rates and wage agreements. We need to have a flexible wage agreement in the tourism industry. Everybody knows that. The honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), when he was a Minister and a shadow Minister, highlighted the need for a change. In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald it was stated:
. . . Mr John Brown called yesterday for a reduction in `outrageous' penalty rates which, he said, were having a `horrendous' effect on the Australian tourist industry.
In another article in the Courier-Mail it was stated:

Horrendous penalty rates are costing jobs. This political organisation, the Liberal and National parties, is prepared to change the position and to deliver those jobs that bring economic benefit to the people of Australia. This Government is not prepared to do that because it is being controlled by the forces of no change, of the status quo, the forces of self-interest and of maintenance of power. That is why we bring this matter of public importance to the attention of the Parliament today. We are prepared to make those changes. As has been outlined by our shadow Minister, we are prepared to bring in these mutually satisfactory wage agreements which would increase efficiency, productivity, wages and jobs that are there for the taking. They now would be created. Our policies would bring those benefits to the people of Australia.

What we would do, which is totally different from what this Government is prepared to do, is let the people of this country determine their own future by enabling them to agree to their own wage awards, to make their own wage agreements. We would ensure that they had a right to determine their future. We would create jobs, promote the economy and increase our productivity and competitiveness. If we do not have those changes we will find that not only the tourism industry, in which I have a great interest, but also every other industry in this country which has the potential to benefit from changes to our award wages, to our wages policy, will miss out.

Over the last few years since I have been a member of parliament we have seen some significant industrial situations. The Mudginberri and Dollar Sweets disputes were two situations in which this Government could have taken a lead, benefiting the people and the workers of this country. But the Government ignored that opportunity. The case of Castle Bacon was a real example of where this Government could have taken a lead. But the Government backed off. Government members sat in the corner and sucked their thumbs.

Some changes need to be made in regard to the Inter-State Commission and the situation on the waterfront. The sum of $800m could be delivered to the people of this country. We will see no action there because, as this matter of public importance which the Opposition brings to the Parliament highlights, this Government does not have the courage or the determination to do what is in the national interest; that is, to ignore the self-interest and the attitudes of the trade union movement and do what is best for Australians, giving us jobs and improving our economy. We are prepared to do that. Let us hope that the next election is called soon so that we get a chance to do it.

What happened to our investment base? It is a very simple mechanism of people working together to help themselves. The Opposition will not join in and it is bagging the system. The Opposition cannot go on having two bob each way; saying that the Government's policies do not work; saying that any attempt to get people working together will not work; and, at the same time, bagging all the constructive measures which have been put in place in an attempt to resolve these problems.

As a nation, we looked at the Opposition's solution; its technique of confrontation; its days of conflict, and we said, `It does not work and we are not going back to it'. . . . that the $109m made available through the Federal Budget for payment of export development grants in the 1988-89 financial year has, unfortunately, been exhausted and in accordance with established procedures, the Commission is seeking additional funds to meet commitments in respect of unfinalised claims lodged in respect of the 1987-88 grant year.

The fourth aspect is industrial relations, and particularly the advantages to small businesses from deregulation and access to voluntary agreements. Members of the Labor Party do not like that. In due course the House of Representatives Committee will offer the Government a report on small business which will be quickly reshaped into a Labor Party small business policy in time for the next election. In contrast, the coalition has a well-established small business policy which is being re-examined presently in preparation for the election. At the core of that policy is a recognition that small business will benefit most from an overall strategy to provide more incentive, more choice, less regulation and a more productive competitive economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I found it slightly offensive when the honourable member suggested to the Committee, which is a committee of the Parliament and, therefore, has some standing in this place, what it is being told. The greatest irony of all is the honourable member for Warringah on the North Shore of Sydney telling me about the restructuring of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you just get the location and the name right?

—That is better, and it is not near Wahroonga.
