SPEECH.PARA: A major factor in re-establishing Australia's manufacturing industry clearly was research and development. The 150 per cent tax write-off on research and development has been a major spur for a number of industries to start investing and redeveloping. The textile, clothing and footwear industry is one of those. The two industries which offer in some ways perhaps the greatest potential of all are electronics and pharmaceuticals. Those industries are now developing at a dramatic rate and in most exciting ways. It has taken six years of long and diligent effort to achieve that. The achievements, essentially, are about repositioning, restructuring and, eventually, reconstructing. There is a flow-on from that. When one visits factories and looks at the new plant, the relationship between management and the work force, their directions, order books and where they are targeting their markets, one finds there has been an enormous change since 1983 and the earlier gloomy years.

In terms of industrial relations in the workplace, it is not a question now of workers versus the boss; it is a question of the corporate team which includes the work force. For the first time in their lives-in some cases it is more than a century-companies are sending tradesmen overseas with management to look at new equipment. In the past there was no way that management would allow a tradesman to go on an overseas trip; that was a perk for management. But much of the equipment management bought was not useable by its tradesmen. Management has learnt its lesson. The award restructuring that is taking place at the moment represents a continuation of that process and certainly offers us the most dramatic change since we first inherited the British guild system last century. That restructuring, particularly in engineering, offers scope for diversity, retraining and enormously increased productivity.

The major key to the future of this country's manufacturing industry is investment. What the honourable member for Warringah did not mention was that the analyses from which we work from the Australian Bureau of Statistics were established over the decades under previous governments of the coalition parties. What is not commonly known is that the money spent on leasing does not figure in Australia's investment figures. So if one tries to compare the level of investment with that of 20 years ago, one finds that amounts spent on leasing do not appear. People have always leased: they have done so for more than 20 years. When one looks at smaller businesses and how much of their plant is leased rather than purchased, one finds the shift to leasing is quite significant. A significant investment has taken place in this country over the last two or 2 1/2 years, largely on a lease basis. Those who want to use investment as published as the major criteria of economic or industrial restructuring are not that well placed. That point was made by the Committee that is conducting the small business inquiry in a report tabled last year.

Other aspects need to be addressed. Most people in our community believe that the Appropriation Bills are about government spending on services such as welfare, pensions, education, health and the like. Of course, most people do not think about the government spending that goes on in an attempt to restructure. The honourable member for Warringah talked about Austrade and the amount spent on export grants. This Government believes that the major need is to get industries effective. We must invest in making them competitive. There is no point in creating incompetent, ineffective and uncompetitive industries and then subsidising their exports. That is what the coalition did for 25 years and that is why we are in trouble. We must make industries competitive with imports in the domestic market and then export competitive. But the concept, which dates back to the 1950s and 1960s, of offsetting our lack of competitiveness and competence with export subsidies so that industries can compete is precisely what this Government has been fighting in Europe, America and Japan for the last six years, eventually with some success. So our task is not to offset our lack of competitiveness by subsidising exports; our task is to make sure that our fundamental manufacturing base is competitive.

To assist in that I believe that the Government should be spending more funds in some areas. I would argue most strongly for the retention of the 150 per cent tax write-off for research and development for a longer period. Our companies are not used to research and development; our companies are not used to competing in world markets. It will take longer than currently assessed for those companies to migrate to the point where research expenditure is a normal part of their budgets. Although quite significant steps have been taken to date to improve quality, I believe that more should be done. There should be more expenditure and more assistance for companies to upgrade their quality of production. If Australian consumers do not believe in the quality of the Australian product, they will buy imports.

What did we specialise in under the previous regime of the coalition? We have a long history of selling the world's cheapest wheat, coal and meat. The only thing that we have sold that was expensive was wool; we have been the world's bargain basement for everything else. Our concentration on quality, which is essential to manufacturing, had been minimal. That is changing rapidly. I believe that companies need assistance, support and encouragement to escalate the shift to quality production.

I mentioned earlier the question of statistics. I believe very strongly in the recommendations made by the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology for a review of our statistics gathering and evaluation so that the Government and we, as parliamentarians, have much more accurate and insightful information about what is happening in our economy. I believe that the statistics we are gathering now would have been more appropriate some 10 or 15 years ago.

I mentioned earlier the heavy engineering plan, which I think has done quite remarkable things for many companies. That concept, which required a combined management and work force committee structure and consultation, has been excellent. Within the award restructuring context I would certainly support the Government increasing our appropriation and expenditure in that area. Quite frankly, I believe that the faster we can move attitudes and the faster we can change within the award restructuring and skills enhancement programs, the more competitive we will be in manufacturing terms.

Eventually, the bottom line of all this is that either Australia makes more things itself or it becomes a degraded economy. We have come very far in six years but we still have as far, if not further, to go. If one goes into the factories of Australia, as I have done in Newcastle for the last six years, and looks at the changes and talks to the people on the work floor and in management one will find that what has been occurring has been quite dramatic and extremely exciting. I am quite confident that we can make those transitions. I think the Government's role in that context is to encourage and assist-not to dictate or provide subsidies to offset a lack of competitiveness; rather to help those companies make that transition.

It is important that we recognise that our industries have been repositioning and rebuilding. I am sick and tired of hearing criticisms about Australian industry that are so badly based. I go to factories of some of the largest industries in the country. The number of politicians, particularly those from the other side of the House, who actually go inside those factories is very minimal. There are very few on the coalition benches who venture into our major organisations and industries. Their capacity to comment on those industries is zero. I can assure the House that those companies have changed and are repositioning. It is important that we recognise and encourage those changes.

Most of all, it is important that we communicate to our public that Australian industry is getting its act together. It has lifted its quality, it has its competitiveness just about right and it has certainly improved its performance. If the Australian community had any lack of confidence or faith in Australian manufacturing years ago-whether it was well or badly earned-nowadays it can certainly look to Australian industries to supply its needs.

Finally, let me rephrase a comment made by the Chairman of the Reserve Bank of Australia about people spending $300 a year less. If every taxpayer in Australia spent $20 a week less on imported goods, whether it be a Mercedes-Benz, a BMW or a pair of Reebok shoes, Australia would not have a trade deficit problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech by the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) was not a bad speech. It is a pity that he got a bit political here and there. Mr Deputy Speaker, is the air-conditioning still turned on?
—I think it is on.

—It is a pretty poor outfit if it is still on. I hope that it is off, because I would hate to think I am getting hot flushes. Tonight I would like to deal with a smorgasbord of matters that I think are not only of interest and significance to the remote and underprivileged areas that I represent but also of immense interest and significance to this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The first matter that I would like to deal with is drought. It may seem strange that, at a time when cyclones are buzzing around in my part of the world and many areas are being flooded, I should bring up the subject of drought. But this is where the difficulty lies. We go through a period of drought, a period of desperation and a period of huge effort by courageous people to survive. Then come the rains and everyone says, `All the graziers and farmers are right again. They are building up huge bank accounts'. I have news for the House and for the nation. Those days are gone. This is an age of survival. God does some funny things. All around my area there are floods, roads are cut and people and planes are bogged down, but 100 miles away in the north-west of Queensland we are still experiencing a drastic drought.

If the points I am addressing now appear to be parochial, I have succeeded in my endeavours. If an industry worth $9 billion is regarded as parochial, this nation has gone into an era of Kamikaze thinking. I propose to present to the House evidence that, when a drought reaches its apex, as has happened in many parts of Australia, people struggle for survival. The people who are involved are the people who made this country. The men on the land not only established industries which will always be there and which are totally necessary for our balance of payments but also were prominent-and I ask honourable members to think back-in placing their lives and their futures in jeopardy when the regrettable wars of the past occurred. It must not be forgotten that in my home area alone two fine people won Victoria Crosses. We do not have Victoria Crosses these days and so we forget what it is all about. We forget what the Australian flag stands for.

Before I proceed further with the views that I want to express as forcefully as I can, I want to give credit to a number of people who helped me correlate and collect this information. Let me give an example. After 20-odd years in this Parliament I am hoping to get the message across that we have to do more than I am doing now-that is, pay credit to these people, say how courageous they are and how they are struggling to survive in times of drought. We say, `We have to do something about this'. One of my former leaders, Black Jack McEwen, used to say, `Never mind about the something that has to be done; tell us what the something is'. I cannot understand why successive governments have failed to anticipate these recurring drought conditions because, believe you me, they will come and go as long as this land exists.

I present to the House and particularly to the Government and the Ministers involved-and that very much includes the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-the following points that could help and would be a substantial contribution to preventing this country from suffering billions of dollars of loss. It is nonsense to suggest that the man on the land-the cocky or the grazier-has his big car and so on. From a material point of view, losses accumulate to a terrifying degree when we are in the grip of these terrible, continuous and inevitable droughts. In time of drought, funding should be more obtainable by simplifying criteria and red tape. Honourable members should talk to these people and hear what they have to go through to get a few lousy dollars to survive and then they would understand why I make this submission to the House and to the Government. It is felt that few people would meet the criteria at any given time to obtain government loans without long delays of weeks and even months. This excludes many applicants from receiving help. Many graziers who were examined were broke but viable.

I plead with the Government to read Hansard and for heaven's sake to act and at least give consideration to these submissions I am making because they come from dedicated men who are still hoping that they will survive-they are probably third generation and fourth generation people on the land. Once a property is drought declared and cash flow is non-existent, $10,000 is to be made immediately available upon application for a concessional loan through an individual's normal banking channel at 6 per cent interest when banks are charging 18 per cent. One of my constituents told me the other day that he has been informed that he will now be paying 20.5 per cent to the bank. How on earth can one make that sort of repayment and still survive?

Could the Government subsidise interest-this is a pretty practical approach-to the bank to bring interest rates up to competitive commercial rates? The eligibility for carry-on finance at concessional interest rates of 6 per cent after two years of continuous drought should be automatic. The ceiling of these carry-on loans is to be raised to $120,000. There was an alleged scandal up in my part of the world recently. A fellow was granted a loan of $100,000. It was said that the Government had given him great concessions and great assistance. He put his head down, was lucky enough to get rain and was able to completely repay the loan in about three years. It is not as though we are investing in a very risky proposition.

Let me make one thing clear: my heart does not continuously bleed for the grazier who may have millions of dollars behind him, is very substantial and never has very much trouble meeting his indebtedness. I am concerned with the small landholder, the small businessman, the carriers and the railway men-all the people who are so totally dependent on the viability of this industry. I am briefly pointing out the terrible difficulties of people who have given their life to the land. These families are having extreme difficulties. Rains, floods and everything else do not wipe out the possibility of future droughts. They will occur. Surely to goodness our parties have the capability of setting up a monitoring organisation that will do everything possible to mitigate drought and make every effort to cushion the effects of future droughts.

I want to talk about a matter that more seriously affected less privileged people. I refer to the declaration of the rainforests for World Heritage listing. I suppose I would have been the greenie to end all greenies when it came to rainforests because in my part of the world if we see one big tree we quiver with excitement. We think, `Oh, there is a tree and a bit of shade. This is just wonderful'. Honourable members can imagine what the people from my part of the world thought of the rainforests when they went to the magnificent Atherton Tablelands and places like that, up along the coastal areas and beyond, on this side of Cairns. I used to get terribly depressed if I thought those rainforests were going to be put at risk. I got a great surprise. I happened to become familiar with the situation when it began to build up-not on a political basis; I ask honourable members to understand that. I began to understand by going into the rainforest and spending hours, days and weeks with foresters that they were not destroying the rainforest. They were making sure that no-one else destroyed them. But that is not my point. Is it not a pretty smart little act to get a group of smaller nations that would not really know where Australia is and would not be concerned about what our future holds or does not hold to gather in Brazil? I do not want to create some diplomatic crisis by naming these nations, but I just say this: it would be a damn sight better if the Brazilian people began to take a greater interest in the destruction of their own very extensive rainforests which we are told are being destroyed at the rate of many acres per second. This is how sophisticated their method of destruction is.

TALK.START.PARA: —The equivalent of one football field a second.

—I am pleased that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business is in the chamber. I really have a great affection for this man. He has helped me in this matter by giving the precise detail. `One football field a second', to quote one of the most distinguished Ministers on the Labor side of the House. Yet the Government will host a group of people who will pass judgment on our nation. Is this not a pretty talented way of infiltrating the affairs of other nations? Surely to goodness the people of a nation are the ones most concerned with the future of that nation, its heritage and its magnificent attributes. Surely to goodness the people of that nation know what they are doing. All that is history now. We have been over all the speeches that have been made in the House. I am concerned with the aftermath, the wreckage that has been left in towns such as Ravenshoe and other centres where these magnificent rainforests existed. These rainforests were magnificent. I see my friend the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) walking past me. He was one of a group of people who visited the rainforests. We spent days familiarising ourselves with all that was going on there. I would like him to visit the area now, to see the rubbish, to see what the pigs have done to these neglected, magnificent rainforests. They are already suffering deterioration. Let me get back to my point. I see, in the declaration of these rainforests as a World Heritage listing, a sinister, talented and unforgiving attempt by small, nondescript nations to pass judgment on and to exercise their influence on our country. On behalf of my people I say that I totally resent it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am presenting a smorgasbord of matters that I think are critical not only to my own area but to the nation. Overall, governments have done a pretty good job with roads. But here and there one finds a vital segment of road which is suffering neglect to a possibly irreparable point. The following may sound parochial, but it is not because it relates to a segment of road which is vital to the defence of this nation. I refer to the Barkly Highway, a segment of the road that runs between here and Darwin. Between Mount Isa and the Northern Territory border that road is crumbling to nothing. We were speaking to the Minister today about other matters. I plead with him to do everything possible, to collaborate with the Queensland Government and the Queensland Minister, to get that road repaired very quickly.

In the five minutes remaining to me I would like to talk about tourism. To go abroad to present a movie is not precisely what the average politician would do, I guess, but I had the privilege of doing so. Paul Hogan was ill or something; he just was not there to present the film. So-would you believe it?-I was chosen to do the job. I was a very questionable substitute; our physiques are not entirely synonomous. But let me get serious about this matter. My secondary responsibility was to monitor the reaction to the film of a certain segment of the American people, the glamorous segment if you like. We spent the first two nights in Hollywood. We then went to Minneapolis and so on. The sort of address I had to give prior to the showing of the film was, `We are going to see a great adventure film. That great adventure land is available to you. Come across to Australia, see our Great Barrier Reef, go into the hinterland, enjoy the thrills and experience that Dundee experienced-not in every respect, but in most of the more adventurous matters'.

Incidentally, I have been to the United States of America since, on a similar assignment. I find that the American people are not so concerned about the Gold Coast. They have bigger and better. They are not so concerned about what is easily the finest harbour in the world, the Sydney Harbour. They are looking for the sorts of things one will find in inland Australia. They are looking for warmth and friendliness and a natural manner. Someone was talking to me the other day about this business of saying, `Have a nice day'. People even say it on the telephone. They finish their call by saying, `Thank you. Have a nice day'. The person with whom I was discussing this said that he answered a woman he was talking to on the phone, `And you drop dead'. People are getting fed up with his sort of nonsense.

I want to promulgate in the House tonight a really Australian package deal which first of all involves a visit to the Barrier Reef or to one of our coastal cities. I am referring particularly to Queensland because, as honourable members will remember, I am talking about the adventure-type holiday which would particularly attract the people of the USA. The interest of Japanese tourists in this type of holiday is accelerating. They are beginning to look for something beyond the fleshpots. The package deal is this: The tourists will visit the Barrier Reef, whether it be off Townsville or Cairns. They will then go down to Winton where they will see the Banjo Paterson country. Overseas tourists probably do not know a damn thing about Banjo Paterson or Waltzing Matilda but what they will see is Australia's natural life. They will see kangaroos-we see too damned many of them, of course-and all that sort of thing. I need not go into the details. They will then go on to the Stockman's Hall of Fame. If I might put in a little plug, I have the great privilege of being the foundation Chairman of the Stockman's Hall of Fame, and my wife is the foundation Secretary. Any other family announcements will be made later! They will then go on to Ayers Rock. They will go from the Barrier Reef to Winton, with all it has to offer, down to the Stockman's Hall of Fame-there is nothing like it anywhere else in the world-and then to Ayers Rock. This is the sort of thing people are looking for.

We have a huge and wonderful potential. I could go on and on. I could talk about tourism for the next three or four days, but it is too damned hot. I wish the maintenance staff would turn the air-conditioners back on. I have mentioned drought. It is critically important that the Government set up the machinery to deal with the effects of drought. I am sure that many people in the Minister's Department could find ways of mitigating the effects of continuous droughts. I have talked about roads and a segment of road that is vital to the security of this nation. I then talked about tourism. I have presented a smorgasbord of matters that are vital not just to my electorate but to the people of this great nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to pay tribute to those men and women in Queensland who over the last two years have experienced both drought and flood. As someone from a family which has been on the land for more than 70 years, I recognise, as does the previous speaker, the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), the contribution that the men and women on the land have made to this nation. It is important that the money provided under the natural disaster relief arrangements go to those most in need. I believe that the Government should continue to encourage the concerns about our soil and land degradation. The Government should ensure that those problems are resolved. As our climate is cyclical, we should encourage the drought-proofing of properties for the droughts in years to come.

SPEECH.PARA: On 28 April 1988 in this House I spoke about natural disaster relief arrangements (NDRA). Earlier this year a Queensland State Government memo from the Department of Primary Industries Drought Secretariat came into my hands. It set out six pages of rorts in the administration of drought assistance in Queensland-drought assistance which received substantial financial support from the Commonwealth Government under the natural disaster relief arrangements. The memo had been written by a diligent officer of the Secretariat who had found evidence of widespread, systematic fraud and wanted to see something done about it.

When the document became public, the reaction of the Queensland Government was not to establish an investigation into this series of allegations. The Queensland Premier, Mr Ahern, dismissed the allegations as some kind of political ploy. Last month the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries described the officer who had written the memo as naive and said that he had been moved to another job. No investigation was initiated by the Executive of the Queensland Government, probably because it knew what it would find. This was at a time when we had experienced severe drought. Now, of course, we have experienced severe flooding.

This was not the first time that there had been public disclosure of rorts in the administration of drought relief in Queensland. In 1986 a former National Party organiser, Michael Behan, received $148,000 in low interest, natural disaster relief loans after the then Queensland Primary Industries Minister, Neil Turner, had directed the Agricultural Bank to lend the money, despite the fact that it had previously assessed the Behan property as non-viable and, therefore, ineligible for assistance under the national disaster relief arrangements guidelines, a fact which was confirmed in 1987 when the Behan property had to be sold because of its debts, despite the receipt of $148,000 in concessional loans. The National Party had tried to help one of its mates. All this corruption went uninvestigated by the Queensland Government. Mr Bjelke-Petersen used the same excuse as did Mr Ahern. The Behan loan was being questioned only as a political stunt. He refused numerous requests from the Commonwealth to investigate. The Commonwealth could not itself investigate these sorts of allegations without the cooperation of the Queensland Government because drought relief is administered by the State. The Commonwealth does not vet either drought proclamations or individual relief applications, nor should it have to duplicate administration at that level. The Commonwealth should be able to expect a State government to administer relief properly, in accordance with the guidelines set down by the Commonwealth. The only check that should be needed is an auditor's certificate saying that the funds provided by the Commonwealth have been expended in accordance with the guidelines.

Because of the Queensland Government's refusal to investigate the Behan loans affair, the Commonwealth Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who administers disaster assistance, two years ago publicly canvassed the option of cutting off Commonwealth funds for drought assistance to Queensland. He did not do so because of the effect that action would have had on those farmers who had a legitimate need for those funds. He did, however, tighten the Commonwealth guidelines. In particular, he restricted the total amount of money which could be provided to one property, thereby at least avoiding the kind of blatant favouritism in the extent of largesse which could be provided, as occurred in the Behan case.

It is important to note that Queensland has used Commonwealth funds for drought assistance to a far greater extent than has any other State. The figures for the last five years suggest that Queensland is systematically milking an arrangement which was set up to help the States and the farmers in genuine cases of need. The States have the constitutional responsibility for disaster relief in times when dealing with an emergency is beyond their own resources.

In the 1984-85, 1986-87 and 1987-88 financial years, Queensland used all the funds spent by the Commonwealth on drought relief. In 1983-84 it used 64 per cent and in 1985-86 it used 91 per cent of those funds. From these figures, one can come to two conclusions: either Queensland has had a bad run of drought over the last five years, or else the funds were not being deployed exclusively for drought relief. The document from the Queensland Drought Secretariat provides the answer-there was an occurrence of widespread abuse and fraud. The document reveals that declarations of individual properties as drought affected have been made in non-disaster situations. Relief has been extended through area declarations to non-droughted properties. Subsidies have been paid where overstocking has produced the same symptoms as drought, effectively rewarding mismanagement. Most tellingly, the document notes that since the existing drought declaration procedures have been adopted, many areas have been drought declared for 50 per cent of the time. This is a higher frequency than could ever have been expected from climatic variation. The document states:
It can be seen the pickings are worthwhile for those prepared to have a go . . .

The document then goes on to outline a number of ways in which the individual applicant can manipulate the system, and gives the example of rail freight concessions. The document, which I stress has been released by the Queensland Department of Primary Industries, states:

Rail freight concessions are also available for droughted sales, agistment and fodder movements. Unfortunately, the railway has even less opportunities for checking eligibilities, and effective checks available to the Drought Secretariat can be circumvented by switching between the two transport systems.
In a section headed `Case Studies' the document states:

Field staff handling hundreds of claims are unable to monitor the happenings on particular properties and ineligible movements are discovered accidentally, well after large sums of irretrievable subsidies have been paid.

Mr Harper's outrageous denials of abuse of the scheme are not shared by his own Department which administers the funds on a day-to-day basis. Mr Harper has been encouraged in his `head in the sand' approach by the Hinkler division of the National Party. It swells the ranks of quango boards in every part of the electorate. Unable to get a job on their own, they rely on Government-appointed taxpayer-funded positions to boost their incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jobs for the boys.

—As the member for Bowman says, it is jobs for the boys. The Hinkler division of the National Party, through one of its spokesmen, claimed the reports were false. That was not a bad piece of arrogance from someone who had not even read the memo. He was the same person who had been calling on wage and salary earners, pensioners and small struggling farmers in Hinkler to give him a subsidy. I have had several complaints directed to me about him. Apparently, he is finding it so tough, he has bought a new $28,000 Toyota Cressida and has taken his wife on an overseas trip. This is evidence of the credibility of the National Party as it tries to tell people it can administer drought relief. No-one would trust the Queensland National Party with a jam jar full of five cent bits when it comes to administering anything.

SPEECH.PARA: Fortunately, the United Graziers Association and the Cattlemen's Union have been the voices of reason in this matter. The United Graziers Association President, Mr Drysdale, was quoted in the North-West Star as saying:
It is clearly in the interests of all graziers and landholders to ensure that drought assistance is geared towards helping those in genuine need.
I fully agree with him. He continued:
If undeserving individuals are abusing assistance measures or are receiving assistance outside the set guidelines then it is up to the responsible department or authority to take appropriate action.

This is precisely what Mr Harper should have done. As the responsible Minister, he should have called for a report into the matter. After all, it is affecting genuine farmers in need. In failing to do so, he has been negligent as a Minister and should be sacked. The Queensland Cattlemen's Union Chairman, Mr David Corr, said in the North-West Star:
Our members realise what is going on. Many experience trouble getting assistance, especially during the period when they are coming out of a drought and need concessional loans to re-stock.
Mr Corr's claims were backed by the Cloncurry Branch President of the Cattlemen's Union, who said on 6 February in the North-West Star:
The drought assistance scheme has been ripped off but no government scheme is water tight against this, and any assistance formula will inevitably be open to abuse from various sections.

The saddest thing this does is to cast a bad light on all farmers. Ninety-five per cent of all farmers are decent, genuine people who work hard to earn export dollars for this country. However, there is a handful of greedy squatters who have had their hands in the pockets of battling farmers, have been ripping off this system and have been protected by the incompetence and lack of will of the Queensland State Government.

I would like to read a few figures from the document: In a drought, when $15m was paid out in subsidies, 84 per cent of subsidy users received subsidies of $5,000 or less. The remaining 16 per cent of users received 76 per cent of all subsidy payments. In other words, 16 per cent of applicants received $11.4m. It is quite obvious that there are genuine people out there who are finding it hard and are missing out on assistance. It is not a case of needing more money, as we have heard from the State Government, which wants an endless supply of Federal money. At the same time, the National Farmers Federation has called for cutbacks of billions of dollars in a bucket which has a hole in it, because the money is not being administered properly by the State Government.

Obviously, it is time for the Queensland Government to have a total review of its own administration of drought relief. It is a damning indictment of the Ahern Government that it has not taken any initiative at all in this area. Yet, it pretends that it prides itself on looking after country people. At the same time, genuine people who are finding it hard are missing out because of a handful of rorters. The Government had to be dragged into this inquiry by Mr Ken Haywood, the Australian Labor Party member for Caboolture, through the Queensland Public Accounts Committee.

There is no point in gutless Queensland National Party politicians, who are afraid to take on the rorters in their own party, pretending this is a case of the Commonwealth Government giving Queensland a hard time. It is a case of Queensland National Party corruption at its worst. We, at the Federal level, have an obligation to ensure that Commonwealth taxpayers' money is not being used to fund this corruption. Most importantly, we have an obligation to ensure that those moneys, which are put there for national disaster relief arrangements, go to those people most in need. We have just seen flooding in Queensland from a cyclone. There will be more applications for NDRA and yet the same guidelines are in place and the same system is open to rorts. We need accountability in Queensland, something which has not happened for 20 years. We also need Mr Fitzgerald to get on a horse, put on an Akubra hat, come into the bush and clean up the rorts in Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject before the House tonight, as some in the gallery may wonder, is the Appropriation Bills. As is always the case, the Appropriation Bills deal largely with the hopefully equitable distribution of the tax money available to the Government. I am reminded of the timeless biblical injunction to render unto Caesar what is Caesar's. With these Appropriation Bills that biblical injunction is being given new meaning, because in 1989 we no longer willingly render unto Caesar; in most instances, it seems that Caesar seizes it for himself. The ultimate irony, the cruellest twist of all for Australia's taxpayers, is that they have been duped into believing that tomorrow night the Government will give them back something. What they do not seem to appreciate is that the Government is handing back to them only what it has effectively already stolen from them.

SPEECH.PARA: The press covering tomorrow night's statement-whether the Adelaide Advertiser or the Sunday Mail-has spoken of a wage-tax trade-off that will be worth between $50 and $70 a week. There has been speculation about how the sum of money is to be equitably split between low and high income earners. Inevitably, as one would expect, there has been lobbying of the Government by tax and welfare groups for some sort of equitable redistribution of whatever money might be available in the tax-welfare and tax-wage trade-off. The point I will continue to hammer during the opportunity I have to address the House tonight is that the Government is not generously handing back something to the people of Australia, but making available to them a little of the excess the Government has at its disposal because it originally took too much. I find that people in my electorate ask me about the state of the economy. They are confused because they hear on one side that the nation is awash with money and that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) intends to hand back in a tax and wage trade-off money to low income groups, a portion to all income groups, and on the other that the nation is broke.

As a result of the devious approach to answering questions employed in the House by the Treasurer the electorate is totally confused. People say to me, `Neil, how can it be that there is too much money in Australia, as the bank manager tells me, when interest rates are going through the ceiling? How can it be that the Treasurer has money available to hand back to the taxpayers of Australia when in our own household budgets there is not enough to go around?'. They are confused because they recognise that along with every other Australian they are tightening their belts, but the standard of living continues to fall. In spite of the belt tightening and the difficulties they have in balancing the household budget, still it is that unemployment rises, that inflation inexorably goes up and that our terms of trade do not improve. So they are confused. They come to me, a non-economist, and ask what is going on.

I have a simple and, I hope, not inadequate illustration of what is currently happening in the nation and I put it to the House this evening. I say to the people in my electorate, a largely rural one, that I believe running the nation is not unlike running the farm. The problem currently facing Australia is just the same as the problem that faces any farmer who discovers that he has more coming in through the farm gate in the form of fertiliser, seed, livestock for fattening and farm chemicals than he has going out in the form of grain for sale, fattened livestock and produce ready to be shipped to market. That is the nation's problem. Just as a farmer discovers more coming in the gate than going out, so the nation currently finds itself importing more than it is exporting to the tune, in January, of $1.5 billion and, in February, almost $1.3 billion-astonishing sums of money. At that rate of stumbling backwards as a nation, the figure for the year would be to the tune of $14 billion or $15 billion.

My constituents then say to me, `That is all very well, but if that is the case how come Treasurer Keating has available money to hand back to us?'. The truth, simplistically, is that we could compare the Treasurer to the farm housewife-I do not mean to be sexist-who says that no matter what happens to the farm she will continue to balance the household budget by charging more rent to all the people who work on the farm and live in the house. So, in the form of taxation, the Treasurer has reaped more and more from all the people who work on the farm, so that while the farm-Australia-continues to go backwards, the household budget-the Federal Government's Budget-is in surplus.

That is a very simplistic illustration, but it serves to remind my electorate and anyone listening of what is currently happening. The Government has money to hand back only because it has already taken too much from the people who live and work in Australia. What Australia-the farm-most needs right now in 1989 in the face of a $1.5 billion or $1.2 billion deficit, depending on the month nominated, just as every farmer needs, is productivity. In order to get productivity, we need some incentive to encourage all those people who live and work in Australia to run a little harder. But any sense of incentive has been totally foreign to the present Government.

What has the Government done? It has applied a capital gains tax so that those who want to be productive and get into business discover themselves being ripped off for their very productivity. It has instituted tax rates which discourage people from being busy and innovative and producing more goods to send out the farm gate. Tax rates under this Administration have gone up, up, up. The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) said that he had instances of Queensland drought administrators who had their hands in the pockets of farmers. He may be right, but if their hands were in the pockets of farmers they would have already found in those pockets another hand, that belonging to the Treasurer, who would have beaten them to whatever happened to be in surplus in the farmers' pockets.

Instead of encouraging people to get on with being productive and having a little more for themselves, the Government has increased the tax take of the nation from $41 billion in 1982-83 to an estimated $82 billion in 1988-89, a record 26 per cent of our gross domestic product. From whom has this money come? At the Australian Labor Party National Conference in 1984 a former Australian Labor Party senator, Arthur Gietzelt, said:

We have in Australia some 120,000 people in the accountants, medicos, pilots and other professional people. We have 313,000 people who are self-employed and that comes to something over 430,000 people . . . as we have to raise more revenue, I think that (the) directions of the Government should be directed towards making that section of the wealthy portion of our society pay their due tax.

Pay their due tax those people most certainly have, in many cases paying between 70 per cent and 90 per cent more than previously. If that were not sufficient disincentive to become enterprising, we also had the implementation of a capital gains tax. What did the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) say to an ALP conference in 1982, before he became the Prime Minister? He said:
A Labor Government must be committed to an effective capital gains tax.
But by 1983, in the face of some electoral reality, he said:
And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.
What did we have? The Treasurer said:

Around the world they (capital gains taxes) never raise much money . . . If the principal reason for government wishing to introduce a capital gains tax were to raise a lot of revenue, we would be damned to fail from the start, because they never raise very much revenue.

If capital gains tax does not raise very much revenue, why are we stuck with it? That tax is, in itself, a major disincentive to all those people who would otherwise choose to invest more in Australian small business, manufacturing and rural enterprises.

In the farm we call Australia, the farm that most needs productive people, this Government seems hell bent on destroying any sense of productivity. Let me quote the Prime Minister again. On the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's PM program on 11 December 1984 he said:

. . . let me make it clear that this is not a country which needs an increase in the tax burden and under my Government it's not going to get it. It's also a country which doesn't need an increase in investment rates and it's not going to get it and that means it's appropriate that we reduce the deficit.
On all those counts the Prime Minister has failed and as a result of his failure there is no encouragement for Australians to be productive.

But I am sorry to say that the picture is even worse than that. In spite of this high taxing Government, in spite of the revenue raising policy we have had from the Government and particularly from the Treasurer, we have had a rundown of the very infrastructure that should have been rebuilt from the proceeds of those high taxes. The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) gave the classic illustration of roads. One would have thought that with the tax collection that this Government has had at its disposal, our road building program would be second to none. The honourable member for Kennedy gave a specific illustration of a road in his electorate that he said had essential defence priority. Let me tell the House again-and I run the risk of boring honourable members, but I will bore them time and time again until something happens-about a specific road in my electorate which also should receive some attention. That road, which runs from the Riverland town of Morgan to the mid-north town of Spalding, is the only unsealed stretch of road between Sydney and Perth. With the capacity that this Government has had to collect tax, that road should have had attention. It has had less attention under this Administration than under any other Administration.

I digress briefly to the subject of wheat deregulation-a subject with which I and other members of the coalition are comfortable. I remind the Government that as we move from obligated rail transport into additional road transport, there will be increasing responsibility on the Federal Government to see that adequate funds are made available to maintain those roads that will enable the grain, which we need to address our balance of payments deficit, to move safely and efficiently to its ports. While I am on the subject of roads I remind the House again of a prime ministerial promise. The Prime Minister said:
Labor-
would honourable members believe this?-
will reduce the price of petrol . . . by the order of 3c a litre.

Less than three years after that statement was made fuel had gone up by 300 per cent and the road infrastructure in Australia was no better-in fact, in many instances it was worse-in spite of that revenue raising measure and the money that must have poured in as result of indexing excise.

The Appropriation Bills before the House tonight make an additional gross appropriation of $684m available to the Government. Some of that money comes from savings, but most of those savings result from programs that have been deferred rather than money that has been pruned from government expenditure. These Bills are set sadly in times of real economic difficulty. All the indicators suggest that we are going wrong. Everyone tells us that the economy is overheated. As I have said time and time again, our balance of payments deficit is becoming increasingly worse and inflation is up. This is not because I pluck any figures out of the air but because the national accounts for the December quarter all sadly illustrate those points. But from the Treasurer and from the Government back bench there is no apology, not even a whisper of change. Instead we hear perpetual invective aimed at this side of the House and we have had to come to terms with it. With monotonous regularity we hear from all Government members in the House, including the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb), who spoke earlier, the allegation that the Fraser years were far worse than the Hawke years. Even if that were true, I fail to see why the Hawke Government should get any comfort from it. If Government members do not use that argument they run the line, `What is the Opposition going to do?'. I thought that the Government was on the other side of the House. The question is what is it going to do, not what are we going to do.

Let me return to my earlier comment about the comparison between the Fraser and Hawke years which is so often paraded in this House as something for which we should be apologetic and of which the Government should be proud. In the little time left to me I wish to run through some comparisons between the events which occurred in the period 1975-83 and those which have occurred in the period 1983-89. In March 1983-not a time when we were exactly proud of being in government-the home loan interest rate was 12.5 per cent; in February 1989 it was 15.5 per cent and rising so that by April 1989 it was closer to 17 or 18 per cent. Under the Fraser Government 4,717 firms unfortunately were declared bankrupt; under the Hawke Administration 7,138 businesses have gone through the hoop. The Fraser average current account deficit was $4.7 billion or 3.6 per cent of gross domestic product; the Hawke average current account deficit has been $11.7 billion or 4.9 per cent of GDP. In June 1983 our foreign debt was $35.5 billion or 20.9 per cent of GDP; by September 1988 that figure had risen to an astonishing $121.2 billion or, would you believe, 40.2 per cent of our GDP. Public housing waiting lists went from 110,000 in December 1982 to 160,00 in December 1988. Under the Hawke Government the cumulative tax is $298 billion whereas under Fraser it was $202 billion for the same period. If honourable members want an even more telling figure I will give them one: in spite of the drought, under the Fraser Government tax as a percentage of GDP was 23 per cent whereas that figure under Hawke has been 25 per cent in what have been good rural years.

Statistic after statistic reinforces the simple fact that the performance of this Government in rurally good years has not been anything like the sort of performance it would have the electorate believe as a result of the efforts of its media machine. The average monthly unemployment under Hawke is 627,000, while the average monthly unemployment level under Fraser was 403,000. These are not figures honourable members will hear from the Government benches, but they present the picture as it is.

I return to my earlier statement: what Australia needs is more productive people. I use an illustration from a former Premier of South Australia, Sir Thomas Playford. When he was picking apples one day he was told by an employee, `I think we need a new tractor'. Sir Thomas turned to the employee and said, `Son, I think we need to pick more apples'. The job in Australia is to get on with picking more apples and to encourage people to do so in order to address our balance of payments deficit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that parts of the contribution of my colleague the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) articulate or throw into very stark relief one of the problems in the Opposition parties. He talked about apples and machines and he talked about Australia being the farm. Sure enough, in part it is; the farm is a very important part of our economy. But it is that approach to the conduct of our nation's economic affairs that has caused many of the problems that currently we are trying to grapple with. The honourable member for Wakefield said that the Fraser years were `not exactly a time when we were proud to be in government'. That is a relevant point. I, for one, would not have been proud to be a member of that Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The essence of the debate is not so much about the juggling of figures. The honourable member for Wakefield did what politicians are wont to do. In so doing he simply confirmed the accuracy of the old adage that there are lies, damned lies and statistics. He adverted to nominal figures, of course, for the unemployment rate. That has to be a grossly misleading approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —Monthly averages.

—Whether monthly or otherwise, he used a statistical base that has to be quite misleading. The smile on my colleague's face confirms it. I want to put a view that would be embraced by most conservative economists in this country. I am not arguing from a partisan perspective in relation to this comment. This is embraced by most conservative economists in this country. Indeed, in so doing they raise some of the concerns they have about the overall level of demand in our economy. Most conservative economists in this country will state, indeed quite accurately, that if the figures for unemployment that are current today were discounted by the quite significantly increased participation rates, that is, the number of women who increasingly have become part of our full time and part time work force, the unemployment rate today would be 3 per cent. That stands in stark contrast to the period that the honourable member for Wakefield conceded was one he was not proud of, when the unemployment rate was 11.7 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: While they are figures and statistics-some people tend not to be too swayed by statistics-the overwhelming reality in terms of those statistics is that they represent hope; they represent opportunity; they represent security for many hundreds of thousands of Australian families. In so doing they represent basic levels of standard of living in many homes across this nation. So, they are not just stark figures. I counsel the honourable member for Wakefield not to be so liberal, or illiberal, in the use of what I would regard as quite misleading statistics.

Some of what the honourable member for Wakefield said I would not argue with. One of the important things about the economic debate in this country is not so much that we should stand up in this chamber and compare sometimes like and sometimes quite incomparable statistics. That is easy for any of us to do. The essence of it is summed up in those two comments by the honourable member for Wakefield. He says that Australia is the farm. Australia is not only a farm. The farm is an important part of our economy, as I indicated earlier. But if we maintain that mentality we will become a quarry.

What Australia desperately needs to do is not to say, `We will go out and physically work harder to pick more apples'. This was an example that the honourable member for Wakefield reflected on. It is an interesting one; I concede that. It probably says a fair deal about Premier Playford, who embraced dying industries for many years in the State of South Australia. He is, in fact, with that most incisive of analytical tools, the benefit of hindsight, one who many Australians would now say was misguided in the approach he took to the management of not only the South Australian economy but the overall national economy. I am not casting aspersions on him. I simply say-I concede, with that most incisive of analytical tools, the benefit of hindsight-that he was wrong. I assert that the honourable member for Wakefield is wrong if he embraces an argument that says, `We will not use machinery; we will just pick apples faster'.

What we ought to be doing is working harder and smarter. There is no doubt that that is what we ought to be doing. In the context of comparing these statistical figures that we heard thrown around tonight, the important thing about this Government, which has caused an awful lot of conflict both within the Australian Labor Party and in the wider community, is that it is the first government, certainly in the post-war period-we cannot compare the period during the First World War and the Second World War because there was a completely different environment-which has grappled with the fundamentals, not the superficial issues, not the ones that get the headlines every day, not the ones that the majority of voters tend to respond to as they will always do. This is the first government that has done something about the fundamentals.

In that context, in identifying the problems that Australia has, it has looked at things like, taking one area, education. We have a record second to none in the Australian context not only in terms of retention rates-they have increased, as everyone in this chamber knows, quite dramatically-and in terms of tertiary places but also in bringing to bear some powers of persuasion about the areas of priority that our educational institutions ought to be pursuing. It is again a matter of great debate, a matter of great controversy. But I think we can rightly claim to be the first to really go about addressing where Australia is going and how particular policy areas and changes in those policy areas relate to an overall economic framework and an overall approach to where we are going as a country.

As I said earlier, an important ingredient of the approach is not only working harder but also working smarter. Those things are intrinsically related. The things we are doing in education and in a raft of other government policy areas are within that overall framework. As a member of the Government Caucus I am in the luxurious position of being involved in the development of many of those policies. There is a theme right across that spectrum. As I indicated earlier about the contribution of the honourable member for Wakefield, it was, as is often the case in this chamber, fundamentally recognisable as an Opposition policy for one central theme. It continues, as the Opposition is wont to do, to point out areas of difficulty. I can tell honourable members that on this side of the chamber I need no education, particularly from the Opposition, not only on the problems that Australia has in a contemporary sense but also on the problems and challenges that we face over the next 20 years. What continues in the Opposition's theme is the absolute lack of policy prescription, the absolute lack of policy alternative put before this House. It is just a continued theme.

I have been here since 1983. I have been through three elections. The one ongoing theme is the lack of Opposition policies. Sure enough, it is the case that the Opposition will come up with advertising slogans. Future Directions is a good example of that. I remind the House-my colleague the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) will be aware of this-that about halfway through last year there was an article in the Bulletin magazine that had Louie the Fly on the front. The article showed a jar of Vegemite and a couple of other things that were evocative of the 1950s. The essence of the article in the Bulletin magazine was that research that had been conducted not only by political party polling organisations but also by a range of other polling organisations indicated a fundamental feeling about moving back to the old days in the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —A nostalgia-led recovery.

—A nostalgia-led recovery, as my colleague so aptly puts it. I said to a couple of my colleagues at that time, `There is no doubt that in the near future this will be translated into Liberal Party policy'. I had occasion late last year to be talking to a group in Canberra and I pointed out the comparisons between the Future Directions policy and that Bulletin article. If I remember correctly, the man who came up with the old Louie the Fly jingle that I remember from my childhood days was the very same gentleman who came up with the Future Directions jingle. So I think there is something to be said about that approach to policy. The honourable member for Wakefield said that it is not up to the Opposition; it is up to the Government. That is as it always will be, but I think Australian electors are now a little more discerning and are not about to be put in a position where they simply respond to a series of assertions with no alternative policy prescription. As I have indicated, that is what the electorate has had to put up with for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: I have moved off at a slight tangent. I was going to talk tonight about what I consider to be an important issue. It is in some ways related to the contribution of the honourable member for Wakefield in so far as he adverted to a range of taxation measures and to such issues as incentive and so on. I want to talk about the relationship between the current business environment, the nation's future business environment, and a hoary old thing called business ethics. In the recent past I have had occasion to be involved as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in a number of inquiries that are intrinsically related to the business community-for example, the mergers, takeovers, and monopolies inquiry and the insider trading inquiry that is currently getting under way. In the course of that involvement I have been struck by what I consider to be the absolute lack of or, if you like, the devalued concept of, business ethics. In that context there is nothing new.

A rudimentary understanding of Australian business history will show that there have been periodic booms and in the course of those booms or bull markets Australian business people have got up to all sorts of misbehaviour. Indeed, there are people in this House, whom I will not name, whose inherited wealth is probably largely derived from what I would consider to be inappropriate or at least unethical business behaviour. Be that as it may, the important issue that I want to address tonight is the broad issue of business ethics and what the Government ought to be doing in terms of the legislative framework to regulate business conduct in this country and, on the flip side of the coin, to encourage decent business behaviour, to ensure that small shareholders can invest in companies safe-or as safe as one can reasonably make it-in the knowledge that their investment will not be arbitrarily removed from them via corporate misbehaviour.

I am talking about trying to establish an overall framework of ethical business behaviour. I can recall the anecdote in the United States of America that if one wanted to be guaranteed of passing a business ethics examination one would simply write down the opposite of what one would do in any business circumstance. That amusing anecdote is probably an important guide in this context. A number of areas are subject to contemporary political debate. They are, for example, in terms of an inquiry by one House of Representatives committee, the use of international tax havens. I would strongly submit that the so-called good corporate citizens of Australian business have a very great deal more to lose by taking the short term advantage of using international tax havens than they will gain over time by applying themselves to the more rigorous business decision making process, the harder decision making process about production, value added, import replacement and export enhancement. They will gain more by following the latter process than they will ever gain by sliding off to some tax haven halfway around the world for the short term benefit of the company from which they derive so many tax advantages and from which they have derived their education. The infrastructure that has nurtured their business does not get a decent return on that particular form of investment.

There is a whole raft of areas of business behaviour that I am finding increasingly offensive and increasingly irrelevant in terms of where Australia ought to be going. They encompass, for example, the creative accounting industry in which so many of my colleagues from my university days are now employed. That industry is absolutely unproductive and is inimical to the development of a productive business based culture in this country. I refer to such things as put and call options, of which all honourable members will be aware, and the misuse of those highly technical and in my view quite unethical and unacceptable business practices. I am concerned also about the insider trading area to which I have adverted, which, of course, is the subject of my Committee's inquiry. I am concerned about where this country should be going internationally.

It is often said by Australian businessmen who are involved in the international area that it is almost impossible to be honest; that one simply cannot win a contract in some countries without slinging money to some crooked intermediary or somehow or other to bribe one's way into a good business outcome. Once again, a long term perspective is probably more important than the short term gain scenario. I believe it is very important for this country to have a reputation just like Qantas Airways Ltd has for safety in flying and good maintenance-a reputation for delivering honest government and business contracts. I believe that in the final analysis that approach would pay clear dividends to the country and to its individual business corporations.

I am concerned about the whole area of warehousing. It is impossible to review the last few years of Australian business conduct without the practice of warehousing being thrown up. This possibly legal-when one divides it up and approaches it in a certain way-method of going about takeovers is grossly unfair to the ordinary shareholders who are usually represented through institutions, simply because it rips off their savings. The small shareholders are being treated like mugs by some of the smarties who parade as great leaders of business in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —And produce nothing.

—And produce nothing, as my colleague from the Opposition has indicated. They are paper entrepreneurs. The honourable member is quite right. That practice does enormous damage to our productive sector. We simply cannot go on allowing these people to bask in the glory of successful entrepreneurship simply because people do not understand how they have gone about achieving their wealth. They have done that in many cases by throwing out any productive culture and any creativity other than a creative accounting culture and using the tax system to advance their own interests, often against the interests of ordinary shareholders, whom the Government should be encouraging to participate.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, I say that it is very important in my view for this Parliament to embrace the theme of corporate morality and corporate ethics. It is not treated seriously, in my view, in the business sector. In fact, it is treated almost as a laughable concept. Increasingly in an international context it is not only taken up as a serious area of academic inquiry but also, importantly, as a serious area of corporate pursuit. People overseas have learned the lessons that I hope we will begin to learn in this country; that, in the final analysis decent long term planning, a decent corporate morality and approach to business ethics, and a decent productive culture will return more to ordinary shareholders and corporations than any smart alec approach to the corporate sector.
Debate (on motion by Mr Millar) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, I present the Committee's fourth report on proposals for variation to the plan of layout of the city of Canberra and its environs.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report is the fourth report prepared by the Joint Subcommittee on proposals for variation to the plan of layout of the City of Canberra and its environs. Section 12 of the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910 deals with variations to the plan of the City of Canberra. The Minister may, at any time, modify or vary the plan. A variation cannot be made until 14 days after a notice of intention has been published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. In practice, the Minister does not vary the plan until the variation and public comment on the variation have been considered and reported on by the Joint Subcommittee.

SPEECH.PARA: This report covers variation 1988-5 which relates to a road addition and deletion in the Gold Creek tourist area in Gungahlin. At present there are a number of tourist facilities at Gold Creek, which have grown around a group of historic buildings, and include a model village, a craft shop, an inn and an art gallery. The area surrounding this existing nucleus of tourist facilities has the potential for the development of a range of tourist oriented uses such as art and craft studios, an equestrian centre or a country town main street. The Joint Subcommittee held a public hearing on the proposal on 24 February 1989 at which officers of the ACT Administration, including the interim Territory Planning Authority, gave evidence.

The purpose of this variation is to provide access to land to the north west of the existing Ginninderra Village. The proposal entails the deletion from the city plan of part of O'Hanlon Place and the addition of a road which will provide access to the land north-west of the existing Ginninderra Village. The Joint Subcommittee was informed that the proposal is to construct a connection onto the Barton Highway and then build a parallel road to the highway which connects into O'Hanlon Place, the small cul de sac off Gold Creek Road. According to ACT Administration, the layout of the road will enable later expansion into the rest of the Gold Creek tourist area.

The ACT Administration intends to stage development. The first stage will provide the Barton Highway junction and a road and services to connect to a service station. The Committee was told that as further sites are needed the road will be extended at that time in a second stage, eventually connecting to O'Hanlon Place. We were concerned to ensure that the location of the road entrance was the most appropriate both from a safety and future development perspective. The Joint Subcommittee is satisfied that the explanation of the ACT Administration about the location of the road takes account of both safety and land access requirements. We also recognise the value of the collocation of tourist facilities in the Gold Creek area. Therefore, the Joint Subcommittee approves variation 1988-5.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am a member of the Joint Subcommittee of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure but, to be fair, it does not get a great deal of attention from me because I have a fundamental belief that much of the Committee's work does not belong in the national Parliament. —I am pleased that the honourable member for Fraser agrees with me. SPEECH.PARA: However, I remain quite angry that it cost several thousand dollars-as I recall it, that was the amount admitted to-in terms of administrative errors, for some very minor alterations to facilitate the upgrading of the United States Embassy's security fence.
