DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1988-89[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1988-89APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1988-89]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this rather late hour of the evening I take the opportunity, briefly, to address the Appropriation Bills being debated cognately. A colleague who was scheduled to speak at this time sought my cooperation to stand in for him because a circumstance arose which prevented him from being here. So with that unexpected opportunity I now proceed to address matters of great consequence as I am mindful that in some 20 hours-plus the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will make a statement to the Parliament and, by extension, the nation which, presumably, will have some important bearing on the state of affairs in this country. I would not presume to anticipate all that he may have to say, but it has been widely canvassed that the package will devolve on a wage increase and a tax reduction.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say again, as I have said on a number of occasions in this House over the years, that I am utterly confounded at the inability of the work force, loosely described, to recognise that not only does it fail to derive benefit from a salary increase, in fact it suffers an adverse consequence. The simple fact is that, taking a notional increase-say, in hypothesis, $10 a week-after taxation, sundry deductions, Medicare and perhaps superannuation, people will be fortunate if they take home $5. But the $10 compounded will go into every solitary item people purchase. So they will not have caught up: they will have actually gone backwards. To compound the matter in the broad-and it affects all Australians-it has a decidedly inflationary effect. Clearly, there would be a significant benefit if any advantage passed through to the work force-again, I emphasise that I use the term `work force' loosely-rested in taxation deductions because instantly there would be a deflationary effect. It would give a real benefit to the recipient, the worker. There would not be an inflationary factor. Indeed, the only problem attaching to that is that it would give the people of Australia a capacity to spend more and that could further exacerbate the problem with which we are currently confronted-too high a liquidity, reflected in turn in excessive imports and a trade imbalance.

But here tomorrow night it appears that we will again witness the extraordinary paradox where a government elected to govern in the interests of Australia feels itself bound to accommodate the expectations and demands of what we might call a surrogate government-that is, the trade union movement-in an objective which does not serve those whom the trade union movement notionally represents. I wonder how long we must go on before the truth of this proposition descends on the people of Australia-the workers of Australia-to ensure that they do not any longer go about compounding their difficulties and the difficulties of Australia. It seems to be a continuing exercise in futility and I lament that circumstance.

One might speak about a number of things in this wide-ranging appropriation debate. Let me just snatch at a few things. Today we discussed in part the problem of the acquisition of Australian land and assets by foreigners and, more to the point, by the Japanese. Arguments have been advanced by honourable members on both sides of the House that this practice should be endorsed and accepted as being in the best interests of Australia and our economy. Unequivocal statements have been made by both the Treasurer and the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), that there should be no intervention on the part of either group and the Parliament as a whole in that arrangement.

A sad message is contained within that. I hasten to say that I understand exactly the rationale of their respective positions. But what it really boils down to is that Australia may have won the war but we unquestionably have lost the peace. This comes about simply because we have elected to loaf in the sun and to delude ourselves into believing that, somehow or other, we are masters of our own destiny whereas we are at the mercy of the global marketplace and we have to measure up with the right article and the right price at the right time. If we fail to compete we lose the ability to accommodate the expectations of our society. Those expectations have become far removed from reality.

We are presently beset with protestations that the young people of Australia in particular are being denied their entitlement in so far as there is an inability to purchase or finance their first homes because of the increasing cost of real estate, extortionate interest rates and associated reasons. But the objections are predicated on the proposition that they have a right to have a first new home. I must admit that, in the passage of my lifetime, I can recall the pinnacle of ambition of a young couple marrying being to find a nice little home to rent and, if they found it, they were in paradise.

By the slow progress of familiarisation with the good times we have come to a stage where we confuse expectation with entitlement or vice versa. This Parliament is now subject to most insistent claims that we must assert ourselves to accommodate the expectations of our people. There is only one way we can accommodate the expectations of our people-that is, to earn the wherewithal to meet the cost of such accommodation. We have an increasing national debt, our trade balances increasingly are adverse, yet we go on believing that somehow we can ignore the harsh reality of these circumstances.

Because we ignore the realities we find that we are virtually impotent to do anything about the purchase of Australian assets and land in particular by nationals of other countries. Some will say that that has been Australia's history. There has been a continuing history of land and asset acquisition by the British, the Americans, the New Zealanders and the Japanese. But that is not strictly true. When we ponder the matter we cannot say that the British were foreigners. We were British. Believe it or not there was a time when Prime Minister Menzies described himself as `British to the bootlaces'. Nobody took offence because that was a fair assessment of the character of Australia. So British investment was not foreign investment. The Americans also were benign, if at times slightly jarring, good friends.

But because of the war the Japanese moved into a different category altogether. It was not just because we were militarily opposed-we were allies in the war before that-but because there is such a conflict in cultures and because many Australians in our defence forces and in the broader society were subject to behaviour which we regard as inexcusable. So it is a tall order to expect Australians to adapt instantly to the notion that their land must be surrendered to non-Australians. But the bitter pill to swallow is that we have nobody to blame for that circumstance but ourselves because we have let the world go by. We have allowed Japan to ascend to a position where it is one of the richest nations on the earth. And it will not stop there.

The Republic of South Korea will be a creditor by 1991, demonstrating a capacity to invest in Australia or anywhere in the world. Buy the place up; that is business. Following South Korea is China. We know the opportunities South Korea has seized from Japan and other nations by its industry, its cheap labour and its prowess. But South Korea will be undersold by the emerging China.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are investing here now.

—That is exactly the way it will go. So no responsible person should delude himself that we do not have to bother; that we can just sit and wait for it all to descend upon us. It has not and it will not. Until we recognise the reality of our circumstances and stop beating around the bush, there is no way in the world that we will resolve the problems with which we are confronted.

SPEECH.PARA: One could ask: What is the prospect of resolving the problem when within this House there is a substantial division of opinion as to who is responsible, what the nature of the problem is, and who will fix it? People outside this Parliament listening to the debate and reading the press would have no confidence in anybody to fix it because the way in which we present ourselves and the way in which we conduct ourselves would suggest strongly that we are irresponsible fools. I cannot accept that. Come this May I will have been in this Parliament for 15 years and I know that there is considerable talent on both sides of this House. But somehow or other the Parliament is not selling itself to the electorate in a real and honest way. Unless we do that we cannot get the confidence of the electorate.

The electorate must have confidence in this Parliament to permit it to do the things essential to the restoration of the good health of the nation. Because of our failure to spell out loudly and clearly the nature of our problems, the electorate has been lulled into believing that all will be well and the problems will be resolved within the parameters of conventionality. We are not within conventional parameters. Australia is facing unprecedented problems and it will require the collective talents of all those within this House and the willing acceptance of the electorate to cope with that which must be inflicted-and I use the word advisedly-upon them to ensure longer term improvement of their circumstances.

Earlier this week and in the course of this debate the financing of roads has been mentioned. Anybody with the slightest familiarity with Australia must instantly recognise the need for road funding. We have a vast country. Road communications are critical to our social development and our economic advancement, but it is also quite clear that the resources of the nation fall far short of the requirement to attain standards in road transport or to facilitate communications commensurate with our desire and our need. Half the population of Australia lives in Sydney and Melbourne. The need for road services in the cities is huge. It could well mop up the entire road funding. On a flyover in Los Angeles a few months ago I found that I was in a compact road network of six vertical levels of road. Can honourable members imagine the cost involved in that?

We say to the government of the day that we need more money for roads. I have no hesitation in saying that I would increase the proportion of our resources going to roads; I consider them that important. But only a fool would venture to say how much we should provide in dollar terms a year hence or two years hence because one does not know what is in the kitty. As an article of faith we should say that we will give it a higher priority; that whatever we have, it will get a higher proportion of a larger slice. Whatever we give will not meet the requirement. If people are insistent on more money for roads, with our limited resources it must necessarily follow that there are only two ways the wherewithal to meet that requirement can be found-through increased taxation--

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1988-89[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1988-89APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1988-89]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for its forbearance to allow me to spend a few more moments to round off my remarks rather than delay the whole procedure tomorrow. The House and I can now sleep with greater peace of mind than might be the case otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: I was just about to say that it stands to reason that if we have an expectation of government finance to improve our road system-there is no limit to the amount that could be required and usefully applied-the wherewithal can only be provided by an increase in revenue, an increase in taxation, or the Government retreating from an area of current expenditure which will make the money available for roads.

It does seem to me something of a nonsense just to continue bleating for more money for any particular area of government responsibility or expenditure without taking heed of the simple truth that money does not grow on trees. There is no money lying around the place. Great store is put on the amount of revenue derived from the motorist in fuel tax. That is a statistical fact that one cannot deny, but to suggest that all the money should go back to roads or to accommodate the expectations of the motorists would raise the question as to whether we should spend the taxation on cigarettes to make mortuaries more comfortable so that smokers who die as a consequence of smoking will find their exit more comfortable. Or should the tax on beer be spent to extend drinking hours or lengthen the bars?

I am being just a little flippant, but the point is that it is a revenue grab to meet the total commitments of the government of the day. So if society is insistent on more money being spent in a particular area, it should indicate its preparedness to go without in another area or, perish the thought, say, `Let us have a taxation increase'.

May I just say on taxation that I lament the performance of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) today when, by skillful use of statistics, he demonstrated that this Government had a smaller percentage of outlays than any previous government. That again was a statistical fact. It was a smaller percentage but measured against the tax grab-the extraordinary revenue intake from increasing taxation by bracket creep and what have you-the percentage meant more dollars towards expenditure and outlays. So the percentage figure was totally misleading. That is fairly typical of the way we carry on here.

I want to say again that there are great expectations out in the electorate getting tattered around the edges, as evidenced by more support than normal for fringe political groups, for those of the pseudo independent character. That in itself must be seen for what it is-an expression of disenchantment. I cannot for one moment allow these people, who no doubt are well intended, the likelihood or possibility of their being able to achieve that which has thus far alluded us.

It rests with us to do the job. The first requirement is to come clean with members of the electorate, to give them the facts of the matter. They are not getting those facts because it is not within the capacity, I venture to say, of any government in a conventional mode to resolve the problems of this country. As I have said, perhaps at the risk of being considered a heretic, traditionally we find governments hesitant about giving the facts to the country because of the electoral consequences.

Indeed, if I can put it in analogous terms, if the Government were to endeavour to convince the electorate that it was afflicted with cancer and that it was necessary to slit its belly from side to side to extract the malignancy and make the electorate well, we would almost certainly find the opposition of the day, whoever it might be, if not asserting, at least implying, that it could cure the cancer by rubbing ointment on the elbow. The patient would suffer the consequences. Perhaps I am demonstrating just a little unreality. Historically we seem committed to pursuing our own objectives and our country often suffers as a consequence.

I have said in this House before that parliamentarians fall short of that which we expect of them simply because they will insist on behaving just like people. They warp logic and the reason of their own desire and have a preoccupation with the next election while the next generation goes down the drain. I know that we are cursed with our personal ambitions. Who is to say who is right and who is wrong? But I am saying categorically and positively that there is no evidence thus far to suggest that the course on which we have embarked and on which we persist will take this country to a position which could be seen fairly as consistent with that which we would wish for it. I thank the House again for giving me the opportunity to conclude my remarks. I trust that I have not disturbed it unduly with my rather revolutionary comments.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Safety Council of Australia, Victorian Division-Beer Prices-Women's Safe Harbour Refuge-Trade Practices Commission

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Hand) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been no recent scandal in Australian public life that has captured the attention of our media and the public at large more than has the collapse of the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia. That division was principally located within my electorate at the West Sale airfield, although it did have bases stretching as far north as Darwin and at a number of ports in between. Some 260 of the 450 employees of the National Safety Council of Australia, Victorian Division, were located at Sale. Needless to say, in all the raging public debate about what has happened, the personal suffering of the 260 employees and their families has been largely forgotten. My task tonight is to remind the House of the suffering that has been imposed on a number of very dedicated and very good people.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing that has been forgotten is that the National Safety Council did perform a great many worthwhile functions. Indeed, I have with me a computer print-out of some 450 missions that the National Safety Council performed in the last 12 months, many of which saved human lives. My concern is that now the Victorian division has been wound up a number of Australian lives are at risk. Indeed, it is no exaggeration to say that Australian lives will be lost because the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council no longer exists. People forget the range of functions that the National Safety Council performed and also forget that it was made up, in certain areas, of the best trained specialists not only in Australia but arguably in the world.

In the little time available to me, let me very quickly go through some of the functions that were performed by the National Safety Council that will now fall onto other shoulders and will probably not be performed to the same level of excellence. In brief, in search and rescue the National Safety Council had twin engine, all weather helicopters fitted with the most sophisticated equipment. There were twin engine, all weather, fixed wing aircraft. There was operational coordination and ancillary equipment.

Let us look now at fire fighting. South-eastern Australia is considered by most experts to be one of the most fire prone areas of the world. In brief, the National Safety Council had 15 fire bombing helicopters, again with very sophisticated equipment. There were fire mapping procedures. There was logistic support. In the area of medicine, four National Safety Council doctors who formed an integral part of the organisation were on call 24 hours a day. Those doctors participated in para-rescue training, enabling them to be dropped into any area to give extra medical support to the initial rescue team.

The National Safety Council provided helicopter ambulances throughout south-eastern Victoria. There was also hyperbaric transport. Divers throughout Australia are seriously at risk without the hyperbaric facilities provided by the National Safety Council. Many training programs were undertaken by the National Safety Council which assisted other search and rescue training organisations. It assisted firefighting organisations such as the State Electricity Commission and the Country Fire Authority as well as offshore personnel. The National Safety Council provided 24-hour industrial emergency services. There was coverage for 365 days a year of rescue, fire and first aid services for personnel in the La Trobe Valley power stations.

I wish to pay tribute to the dedicated people of the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council. Now that that organisation appears to have been scattered to the four winds and the ground it once occupied ploughed, I very much fear that Australian lives will be lost. The level of services that the Council once provided in a unique way simply cannot be duplicated. The tragedy of the collapse of the National Safety Council is that Australian lives will be lost. What was once one of the world's leading safety organisations no longer exists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to speak tonight about a matter that has been raised with me by many electors in my area, the price of beer in Perth. What is in question is the pricing structure used by Bond Brewing and Carlton and United Breweries Ltd. For a carton of two dozen 375-millilitre cans of Tooheys Draught purchased from the Coles Liquorland chain in Sydney one will pay $18.99. I make the following comparison because Bond Brewing produces that product in New South Wales. Bond Brewing also produces a product in Western Australia, Emu Export lager, or Swan Premium lager. So there is no transport cost differential in both markets. One would pay $22.59 in Perth for Bond Brewing's local product compared with $18.99 in Sydney. In other words, there is a $3.60 difference in the price per carton asked by the Liquorland chain in Sydney and Perth. In effect, people who choose to drink Bond Brewing beer in Perth, the local product, are being charged, unnecessarily, an extra $3.60 per carton. Honourable members should bear in mind that there is no differential in transport costs because both beers are produced locally in the two markets.

SPEECH.PARA: What is even more alarming-I find this interesting-is that if one chooses to buy the Bond Brewing products Emu Export lager or Swan Premium lager in Canberra, one will pay $19.99 a carton. It has been shipped all the way from Western Australia, but one pays only $19.99 a carton. That is cheaper than the product in Western Australia, where one pays $22.59. In other words the product is $2.60 a carton cheaper in Canberra than it is in Western Australia.

How does Bond Brewing justify that price differential? Clearly, there is a problem that we have to address. It is also very disturbing that the price, in metropolitan Perth, of a two-dozen carton of 375-millilitre cans of Fosters lager, is $22.59, which happens to be identical to the price being charged by Bond Brewing. I ask people to draw their own conclusions. One could draw many conclusions, but one very clear conclusion is that there is no price competition. That is a matter in which the Trade Practices Commission would be interested. There is no effective price competition. This matter deserves further investigation because people in Western Australia are being disadvantaged.

Not only do we have no competition but also we have an unjustified price differential. People in Western Australia are paying $2.60 a carton more than people in Sydney pay for a similar product shipped right across Australia. What is also very telling is that a locally produced product in New South Wales, Tooheys Draught, costs $18.99 at Liquorland, yet the comparable locally produced product in Western Australia, Swan Premium or Emu Export, is $22.59 a carton. There is a $3.60 difference in price. It is up to the brewer, in this case Bond Brewing, to justify that. Many of my constituents have said that they do not believe it is justified. I can see no justification for it whatsoever. What is also worrying is the price difference between the Carlton and United product in Western Australia and the Bond Brewing product. As I have said, there is no effective price competition.

If one takes a national comparison, State by State, one finds that the price of beer depends upon the market. If one looks at the Brisbane market, where Power Brewing is providing effective competition with Fourex, one finds that much lower prices are being charged by the Fourex brewery compared with what it would charge in Western Australia. A carton of Fourex in Brisbane costs $19.82 compared with, again, $22.59 for the product in Western Australia. There is no justification for it. When one looks at such price structures one sees no evidence of price competition. There is clear evidence that there is an attempt to arrange a market structure which certainly disadvantages ordinary people. It is clearly not the intention of this Government that that sort of non-price competition should be occurring. In effect, there is an absence of price competition. Drinkers in Western Australia are being asked to pay a premium over and above what they would pay if they were drinking similar Bond Brewing products in New South Wales or Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to extend my earlier remarks regarding the National Safety Council of Australia (NSCA). In the days before the provisional liquidator finally found it necessary to close the doors on the West Sale base of the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council I spent a considerable time with its employees and their families. One occasion which will be forever remembered by me was a quickly called together barbecue on the Wednesday night prior to the Friday afternoon closing which was attended by almost all of the 260 employees and many of their families. It was obviously something of a wake, but at the same time it was a demonstration of the spirit and determination, even courage, of the employees as they awaited their inevitable fate.

SPEECH.PARA: What one has to understand about the employees of the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council is the dignity and strength they showed as public controversy raged around them throughout Easter and the following week. There was never any damage on the base or any theft, despite the fact that some of the pilots are owed more than $50,000 in unpaid leave and superannuation. Almost everybody on the base will suffer considerably regarding wages owing to them. It was a measure of their pride in their work that, in that final week they were able to continue rescue missions and, in some cases-it was universally agreed-save some lives.

These people are now in a state of despair. Many of them moved to Sale to join the NSCA, some of them as recently as the last couple of months. They left, for instance, secure positions in the armed forces or the police forces. Some of them were pilots, some operational officers. Some were near pension time, but they left to take what they thought were positions with Australia's premier search and rescue organisation. Some of them cannot afford to remain in the Gippsland area. They will have to leave and seek work elsewhere. A number of them will not be able to find work. Some of the pilots will be able to find work, but many of the specialist operational rescue people simply will not be able to.

It is a tribute to them that throughout the time between the public collapse of the Victorian Division and the final winding up they were able to carry out their duties. All of them left the base for the last time with their heads held high. They pose the same question I pose to State and Federal governments: What organisation, what personnel, will replace them? It was the National Safety Council of Australia that specialised in off-shore search and rescue; hyperbaric medicine and services; aerial water firefighting; helicopter underwater escape training; remote sensing; helicopter ambulance and industrial emergency services. Let us take, for example, a maritime collision somewhere in Bass Strait, or anywhere in Australia for that matter. Who could respond to such an emergency? The Royal Australian Air Force, itself, states that it cannot respond in under less than an hour, and possibly three hours, because it cannot assemble the crews.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no pilots.

—There is a shortage of pilots and it does not have the equipment. Its aircraft would be either the Hercules at the Richmond base, or the Orions at Edinburgh in South Australia. If there were a maritime collision in Bass Strait, for instance, a maritime route which experiences very heavy traffic, who would get there? What helicopters would have the winch equipment? The Esso helicopters would, but they would have to be specially fitted out and a crew assembled, so the response time now throughout Australia for emergencies, in some cases, will be greatly lengthened. That puts at risk a great many lives.

SPEECH.PARA: It is imperative that the Federal Government, through the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), very closely examine the whole problem of what, or who, replaces the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia. I very much fear that not nearly enough attention has been given to this aspect of that Council's collapse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about a unique group in Australia known as the Women's Safe Harbour Refuge. It is the only group in Australia which cares for alcoholic women and their children.
—We do.

—Let me say that the Women's Safe Harbour is the only group in Australia which happens to acknowledge that alcoholic women can be rehabilitated within society. The refuge is the work of two very excellent women whom I have admired for quite some time. Those women are Norma O'Connor and Robyn Mason.

SPEECH.PARA: Norma O'Connor was an alcoholic and is now a sober alcoholic. She has been sober for 11 years. Her sobriety should be acknowledged by this House. She joined Alcoholics Anonymous on being urged to do so by her young son, who was killed by a drunk driver three years after she joined AA. In anybody's language, this would have driven anyone back to drink, but it did not have this effect on Norma. She pursued, and worked for, the rights of alcoholic women to live and to work with their children. She believes that those women who acknowledge their alcoholism, who work through the detoxification unit, and who then are willing to become sober alcoholic women in the community, have only one thing to live for-their children.

With Robyn Mason, another ex-alcoholic, Norma O'Connor established the refuge for alcoholic women in our community, called Safe Harbour. This refuge provides and has provided for, large numbers of women and their children within the Queensland and Brisbane community. It is the only refuge of its kind in Australia, because, as honourable members know, alcoholic women are usually isolated from the community. Many people here know that alcoholic men normally have their wives to look after them. Let me tell this House that alcoholic women never have their husbands to look after them and they never have their families. In Australian society, alcoholic women are totally isolated from the rest of the community. Safe Harbour acknowledges this fact, but more importantly, it acknowledges that alcoholic women need their children for their rehabilitation. Safe Harbour has been so successful in the rehabilitation of alcoholic women, that it has drawn large numbers of people within the field from both America and the United Kingdom. It is the only refuge in Australia which is prepared to acknowledge that alcoholic women need their children, need to work and need to successfully rehabilitate within the community. Safe Harbour has been successful to the point where only two women who have been through it have returned to their alcoholism.

I acknowledge the work of not only Norma and Robyn but also the committee as a whole. I urge this House to look upon the work which has been done by the Safe Har-bour Refuge for alcoholic women and their children. This is a milestone within Australia and in the rehabilitation of women. It is also a milestone in the world context. It has been acknowledged by the world community as a method by which alcoholic women may be and are rehabilitated within the community. We see here a group of women who were previously dependent upon alcohol who have become, through their own work and through the support of the Safe Harbour Refuge and Alcoholics Anonymous, which works through the Safe Harbour organisation, independent human beings who are able to provide for themselves and their children a worthwhile and meaningful life, free of the dependency not only of alcohol but also of the government system. I urge that all members of the community support such groups as Safe Harbour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) was talking earlier tonight about the competitiveness in the beer industry. I know that some people in the Australian Labor Party know a great deal about some of the beer barons. He made the point that the Trade Practices Commission--
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. As I understand it the chief beer baron of this country is the President of the Liberal Party.
—This is a frivolous point of order.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will resume his seat when a point of order is being taken. He has been here long enough to understand that. I did not quite hear the Minister's point of order.

—It was that a reference was made to members of the Labor Party knowing well the beer barons of this country. I was pointing out that the chief beer baron of this country is the Federal President of the Liberal Party.
—The honourable member for Mayo might have been right; there is no point of order.

—I will certainly remember that, Mr Deputy Speaker. I did point out that there was no point of order, and once more I am vindicated. I am right. I am right also about the very close associations between the Labor Party and a beer baron in Western Australia, but I will not talk about that. I am going to talk about the issue of competitiveness. The honourable member Stirling made the quite legitimate point that there needs to be effective competition in the marketplace. The genius of the capitalist system is that it operates through competitive markets.
—Ha, ha, ha!

—I know that the honourable member for Throsby does not support the capitalist system, nor does the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) who is at the table. I heard the speech made by the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) earlier tonight and his damning of the capitalist system. I am collecting quite a lot of these quotes; they will certainly make very interesting reading during the next election campaign. The genius of capitalism is competition. The Labor Party, when it suits it, talks about the need for competition. When it does not suit it it talks about the need to maintain monopolies. It is like a lot of its public sector monopolies and it does not believe that competition will work there. Apparently the honourable member for Stirling thinks that somehow competition will work in the beer market. On that point he is absolutely right.

SPEECH.PARA: The instrument that this Parliament has established to ensure that we have competitive markets is the Trade Practices Act and its handmaiden the Trade Practices Commission. What is interesting is the way this Government has treated the Commission with such disdain. Over the period of this Government, public sector spending in real terms has increased by 24 per cent, yet outlays on the Trade Practices Commission have declined by 7 per cent. That is a measure of the seriousness that this Government attributes to the Trade Practices Commission. That Commission needs the resources to ensure that we have a proper competitive marketplace in Australia. When we come to government we will make sure that works properly.
